Understanding Business Activity.definition: An organization that produces goods or services to satisfy customer needs and wants while making a profit.
A person who takes the financial risk of starting and managing a new venture.
Money invested in a business by the owners.
Another word for business, often used when describing a new business.
A person who purchases goods and services for personal use.
Basic requirements essential for survival, such as food, water, shelter, and clothing.
Desires for goods and services that are not necessary for survival but improve quality of life.
The challenge of allocating limited resources to satisfy unlimited wants.
The resources used to produce goods and services: land, labour, capital, and enterprise.
Natural resources used in production, such as minerals, forests, water, and land area.
Human effort, physical and mental, used in the production of goods and services.
A situation where resources are insufficient to meet all human wants.
The next best alternative forgone when making a decision.
Focusing production on a limited range of goods or services to gain efficiency.
Splitting production into separate tasks and assigning each worker a specific task.
The difference between the selling price of a product and the cost of bought-in materials and components.
Organizations engaged in producing goods or services to satisfy needs and wants.
Industries that extract and use natural resources, such as farming, fishing, and mining.
Industries that manufacture goods using raw materials from the primary sector.
Industries that provide services to consumers and other businesses.
Industries that provide knowledge-based services such as research, ICT, and consultancy.
An economy with a combination of private and public sector ownership and control.
An economic system where the government makes all decisions about resource allocation.
An economy where decisions on production and prices are determined by supply and demand with minimal government intervention.
The part of the economy owned and operated by individuals and businesses for profit.
The part of the economy owned and controlled by the government.
The process of growing the manufacturing sector of an economy.
The decline of the manufacturing sector in an economy.
A document outlining a business’s objectives, strategies, target market, and financial forecasts.
The total value of capital used for the acquisition of profits in a business.
Business expansion achieved through increasing sales and output rather than through mergers or takeovers.
Business expansion achieved by merging with or acquiring other businesses.
When one business acquires control of another business by buying its shares.
When two businesses join together to form one new business.
When two businesses in the same industry and at the same stage of production merge or are acquired.
When a business merges with or takes over another business in the next stage of production.
When a business merges with or takes over a supplier at an earlier stage of production.
When a business merges with or acquires another in a completely unrelated industry.
A growth strategy involving entry into new markets with new products.
A business owned and run by one person with unlimited liability.
A business owned by two or more people who share profits and responsibilities.
A company whose shares are privately held and not available to the public.
A company whose shares are traded on the stock exchange and available to the public.
Organizations owned and run by members who share the benefits.
A share of the company’s profits paid to shareholders.
A yearly meeting of shareholders to discuss company performance and elect directors.
A document that defines the responsibilities of directors and the handling of the company’s affairs.
A document outlining a company’s structure and purpose, required for incorporation.
An agreement where one business allows another to trade under its name and sell its products.
A person or business that buys the rights to operate under a franchise’s brand.
A business that grants a franchise to others.
A payment made to the franchisor based on sales revenue.
A business arrangement where two or more parties agree to work together on a project.
Organizations owned and run by the government.
Businesses with a separate legal identity from their owners.
Businesses where there is no legal distinction between the owner and the business.
Specific, measurable goals that a business aims to achieve.
A business that aims to achieve social objectives as well as making a profit.
People within a business who have an interest in its performance, such as employees and managers.
Individuals or groups outside a business affected by its operations, such as suppliers and the community.
When the interests of different stakeholders are in opposition.

People in business.definition: The internal and external factors that stimulate desire and energy in people to be continually interested in and committed to a job or role.
A motivation theory suggesting that human needs are arranged in a hierarchy, from basic physiological needs to self-actualization.
The realization of one's full potential and personal growth after all other needs are satisfied.
The need for self-respect, recognition, and respect from others.
The human requirement for love, friendship, and belonging.
The need for personal safety, financial security, health, and protection from harm.
Basic human needs for survival, such as food, water, shelter, and sleep.
Payment to a worker, usually calculated by the hour or day, based on the time worked.
Factors that increase job satisfaction and encourage greater effort, such as achievement and recognition.
Workplace conditions that prevent dissatisfaction but do not necessarily motivate, such as salary and work environment.
A theory that workers are primarily motivated by money.
Payment based on the amount of time worked.
Payment based on the number of units produced.
A fixed regular payment, typically paid monthly, not dependent on hours worked.
An additional payment given to employees as a reward for performance.
Payment to a salesperson based on the value or number of sales made.
A system in which employees receive a share of the company’s profits.
The practice of moving employees between different tasks to increase variety and skills.
A group of employees working collaboratively to achieve a common goal.
The process of developing employees' skills and knowledge to improve performance.
Advancing an employee to a higher-level position within the organization.
Increasing the range of tasks performed by an employee to reduce monotony.
Increasing job depth by giving employees more responsibility and autonomy.
Altering the structure of a job to make it more motivating and efficient.
The way in which the roles, responsibilities, and authority are arranged in an organization.
A diagram showing the internal structure of an organization.
A system in which members of an organization are ranked according to their level of authority.
A layer of management within an organization.
The line of authority within an organization.
The number of subordinates a manager is directly responsible for.
Managers who have direct responsibility over subordinates.
Employees who oversee and guide the work of other employees.
Managers who support line managers by providing advice and services.
Assigning responsibility and authority to a subordinate to carry out specific activities.
Different approaches to leading and managing people.
A leadership style where the leader makes decisions without input from others.
A leadership style where the leader involves team members in decision-making.
A leadership style where the leader gives employees freedom to make decisions.
An organization of workers formed to protect and promote their rights and interests.
Negotiations between employers and trade unions over pay and working conditions.
Measures taken by employees, such as strikes, to enforce demands.
A workplace where all employees must be members of a trade union.
The process of attracting suitable candidates for job positions.
The process of choosing the most suitable candidate for a job.
The process of gathering information about the duties and skills required for a job.
A detailed outline of the duties, responsibilities, and reporting relationships of a job.
A statement of the qualifications, skills, and experience required for a job.
Filling job vacancies with existing employees from within the organization.
Filling job vacancies with candidates from outside the organization.
An employee who works fewer hours than a full-time employee.
An employee who works the standard number of hours set by the employer.
Training given to new employees to introduce them to the organization and their role.
Training conducted while the employee is performing their job.
Training away from the workplace, such as in a classroom or training center.
Ensuring the right number of employees with the right skills are available when needed.
When an employer ends an employee’s contract due to poor performance or misconduct.
Dismissal based on valid reasons such as misconduct or redundancy.
Dismissal without a fair reason or without following proper procedures.
When a job is no longer needed and the employee is let go.
A legal agreement between an employer and employee outlining terms and conditions of employment.
A legal body that resolves disputes between employers and employees.
Choices made based on moral principles and values.
The process of transferring information from one person to another.
The information or content being communicated.
Communication between people within the same organization.
Communication between an organization and people outside it.
Communication where information flows only in one direction without feedback.
Communication where the receiver can provide feedback to the sender.
Official, structured communication following the organization’s hierarchy.
Unstructured communication that takes place outside official channels.
Obstacles that prevent effective communication.
Specialized terms used by a particular profession or group that may not be understood by others.

Marketing.definition: The process of identifying, anticipating, and satisfying customer needs profitably.
An individual or business that purchases goods or services from a company.
The tendency of customers to continue buying from the same brand over time.
The strategies and technologies businesses use to manage and analyze customer interactions to improve relationships and retention.
The percentage of total sales in a market accounted for by one business or product.
A person who uses goods and services for personal consumption.
Selling the same product to a large market with no attempt to target specific groups.
Targeting a specific, well-defined segment of the market.
A group of consumers with similar characteristics or needs.
Dividing a market into distinct groups of consumers with similar needs or characteristics.
Dividing the market based on location such as country, region, or city.
Dividing the market based on lifestyle, values, attitudes, and personality.
Dividing the market based on characteristics such as age, gender, income, or education.
The process of gathering and analyzing information about consumers’ needs and preferences.
The collection of new, first-hand information directly from sources such as surveys or interviews.
Using existing data collected by others, such as reports or statistics.
A business approach focused on product quality and innovation rather than customer needs.
A business approach that prioritizes identifying and meeting customer needs.
The amount of money a business allocates to marketing activities over a set period.
A set of written questions used to collect information from respondents.
A method of collecting data from respondents via the internet.
A method of gathering information through face-to-face, telephone, or online conversations.
A small group of people brought together to discuss their views about a product or service.
Selecting a portion of the population to represent the whole for research purposes.
A sampling method where every individual in the population has an equal chance of being selected.
A sampling method where researchers select participants to fit specific characteristics.
The combination of Product, Price, Place, and Promotion used to market a product.
A feature or benefit that makes a product different from and better than competitors’ products.
The name given to a product or range of products that distinguishes it from competitors.
The commitment of consumers to repurchase a brand's products consistently.
The perception of a brand held in consumers’ minds.
The design and production of containers or wrappers for a product.
The stages a product goes through: introduction, growth, maturity, and decline.
Methods used to prolong the maturity stage of a product’s life, such as updates or new markets.
The stage in the product lifecycle where sales growth slows or levels off.
When the market for a product is fully supplied and sales growth stops.
Setting a price by adding a fixed percentage to the cost of producing a product.
Setting a price based on what competitors are charging.
Setting a low price to enter a market and attract customers quickly.
Setting a high price initially and lowering it over time to attract different customer segments.
Temporarily reducing the price to increase short-term sales.
Adjusting prices based on current market demand and supply conditions.
A measure of how sensitive quantity demanded is to a change in price.
When a small change in price causes a large change in quantity demanded.
When a change in price has little effect on quantity demanded.
The route a product takes from the producer to the consumer.
A business or person that helps distribute products from producer to consumer.
An intermediary who negotiates sales on behalf of a producer.
Activities to inform and persuade customers to buy a product.
Paid communication intended to inform, persuade, or remind customers about products.
Advertising designed to give information about a product’s features and benefits.
Advertising aimed at encouraging customers to buy by appealing to emotions or desires.
The specific group of consumers a marketing campaign is aimed at.
Short-term incentives to encourage purchases, such as discounts or free samples.
A sales promotion where customers buy one product and get another free.
Activities aimed at creating and maintaining a positive image of a business.
Financial support for an event, activity, or organization in return for publicity.
Including a product in media content as a form of advertising.
Using social media platforms to promote products and engage with customers.
Encouraging customers to share a marketing message to spread it rapidly.
Buying and selling goods or services over the internet.
The goals a business aims to achieve through its marketing efforts.
A plan of action for promoting and selling products to achieve marketing objectives.

Operations Management.definition: A measure of the output produced per unit of input, such as per worker or per hour.
Producing goods and services using the least amount of resources without waste.
A reserve of goods kept to ensure supply in case of unexpected demand or delays.
A production method focused on minimizing waste while maintaining quality.
A production strategy where materials and components arrive exactly when needed to reduce inventory costs.
A philosophy of continuous improvement involving all employees.
Producing custom goods one at a time to meet specific customer requirements.
Producing a group of identical products together in a batch before moving to the next batch.
Producing goods in a continuous process along a production line.
Computer-Aided Design – using computers to create, modify, and test product designs.
Computer-Aided Manufacturing – using computers to control and manage production machinery.
The level of sales at which total revenue equals total costs, resulting in no profit or loss.
The difference between actual sales and the breakeven level of sales.
A cost that does not change with the level of output.
A cost that changes directly with the level of output.
Selling price per unit minus variable cost per unit; used to cover fixed costs and profit.
Cost advantages that a business experiences as it increases production.
Cost savings from buying raw materials in bulk at lower prices.
Lower marketing costs per unit when spreading costs over larger output.
Access to finance at lower interest rates due to larger size and stability.
Specialist managers improve efficiency, reducing costs per unit.
Cost savings from using more efficient, specialized production equipment.
Rising average costs when a business becomes too large and inefficient.
The standard of a product measured against set requirements or customer expectations.
The process of checking products to ensure they meet required standards.
A system ensuring quality is maintained throughout the production process.
A company-wide approach to continuous quality improvement, involving all employees.

Financial Information and Decisions.definition: The initial money needed to start a business, covering expenses before revenue is generated.
The difference between current assets and current liabilities, showing short-term financial health.
Spending on fixed assets such as buildings, machinery, or vehicles.
Spending on day-to-day operating costs such as wages and utilities.
Money raised from within the business, such as retained profits or asset sales.
Money raised from outside the business, such as bank loans or share issues.
Small loans provided to entrepreneurs in developing countries who lack access to traditional banking.
Raising finance by collecting small amounts of money from many people, often via the internet.
Selling accounts receivable to a third party to get immediate cash.
Profits kept in the business instead of being paid out as dividends.
A type of long-term loan to a business, usually secured against assets.
Buying an asset by paying in installments while using it; ownership passes after final payment.
Money borrowed from a bank, to be repaid with interest over an agreed period.
A contract allowing the use of an asset without owning it, in exchange for regular payments.
An arrangement allowing a business to buy goods and pay for them later.
Non-repayable funds provided by the government to support businesses or projects.
Investment from individuals or firms in exchange for equity in high-risk businesses.
Selling shares of the company to raise capital.
Money coming into a business from sales, investments, or financing.
Money leaving a business for expenses, purchases, or repayments.
The time between paying for goods and receiving cash from their sale.
An estimate of future cash inflows and outflows over a period.
The difference between total cash inflows and total cash outflows in a period.
Financial records summarizing a business’s transactions and performance.

Financial Information and Decisions.term: Income Statement / Statement of Profit and Loss
Financial Information and Decisions.definition: A financial report showing revenue, expenses, and profit over a period.

Financial Information and Decisions.term: Balance Sheet / Statement of Financial Position
Financial Information and Decisions.definition: A snapshot of a company’s assets, liabilities, and equity at a specific point in time.
The total cost of producing goods sold during a period.
Revenue minus cost of sales.
Costs incurred in running the business excluding cost of sales.
The profit remaining after all expenses, including taxes and interest, are deducted.
The cost of borrowing money, such as interest payments.
The reduction in value of an asset over time due to wear and tear.
The portion of net profits kept in the business after dividends are paid.
Part of the income statement showing sales, cost of sales, and gross profit.
Resources owned by a business that have economic value.
Assets kept for long-term use, such as buildings and machinery.
Assets expected to be converted into cash within a year.
Debts or obligations owed by a business.
Debts due for repayment after more than one year.
Debts due for repayment within one year.
The value of ownership interest in the business.
Money invested in a company by shareholders in exchange for shares.
The total value of all long-term funds invested in a business.
The ability of a business to meet its short-term financial obligations.
A liquidity ratio comparing current assets to current liabilities.
A liquidity ratio comparing quick assets to current liabilities, excluding inventory.
When a business does not have enough liquid assets to meet its short-term debts.
The ability of a business to generate profit.
Net profit as a percentage of revenue.
Gross profit as a percentage of revenue.
Return on Capital Employed – a measure of profitability relative to capital invested.

External Influences on Business Activity.definition: The total value of all goods and services produced in a country over a period.
A period of strong economic growth and high levels of activity.
An increase in the output of goods and services in an economy over time.
A period of negative economic growth lasting at least two consecutive quarters.
A prolonged period of economic stagnation and low activity.
A sustained increase in the general price level of goods and services.
A sustained decrease in the general price level of goods and services.
The situation where people who are willing and able to work cannot find jobs.
The condition where all available labour resources are being used efficiently.
An increase in a country's production of goods and services over time.
A record of all economic transactions between a country and the rest of the world.
When a country exports more goods and services than it imports.
When a country imports more goods and services than it exports.
A fall in the value of a country's currency relative to other currencies.
An increase in the value of a country's currency relative to other currencies.
Government policy on taxation and spending to influence the economy.
Government or central bank policy on money supply and interest rates.
Government measures to increase the productive capacity of the economy.
The transfer of ownership of a business from the public sector to the private sector.
The transfer of ownership of a business from the private sector to the public sector.
Taxes paid directly to the government by individuals or businesses, such as income tax.
Taxes levied on goods and services, such as VAT or sales tax.
Financial assistance given by the government to support certain industries or activities.
The income left after paying taxes, available for spending and saving.
Income adjusted for inflation, showing the purchasing power of earnings.
Taxes on imported goods to make them more expensive and protect domestic industries.
A limit on the quantity of a product that can be imported.
The obligation of businesses to act in ways that benefit society.
Organizations that try to influence business or government policies.
Costs or benefits of an activity experienced by third parties who are not directly involved.
The cost of an activity borne by the individual or business undertaking it.
The benefits of an activity enjoyed by the individual or business undertaking it.
Costs imposed on third parties as a result of an activity.
Benefits enjoyed by third parties as a result of an activity.
The total cost to society of an activity, including both private and external costs.
The total benefit to society of an activity, including both private and external benefits.
Development that meets current needs without harming the ability of future generations to meet theirs.
The increasing interconnectedness of economies, cultures, and societies worldwide.
Refusing to buy products from a company to protest against its policies or practices.
Choices made based on moral principles and what is considered right or wrong.

The basic economic problem.definition: Natural resources used in production, such as minerals, water, forests, and land area.
Human effort, both physical and mental, used in producing goods and services.
Man-made resources such as machinery, tools, and buildings used in production.
The ability and willingness to take risks and organize other factors of production to create goods or services.
The condition where resources are limited but wants are unlimited.
Basic requirements essential for survival, such as food, water, and shelter.
Desires for goods and services that improve quality of life but are not essential for survival.
Goods that are scarce and have an opportunity cost.
Goods that are abundant and have no opportunity cost, such as air.
Individuals who take risks and organize the factors of production to start and run businesses.
The ease with which workers can move between different jobs or locations.
The total number of people available and willing to work in an economy.
The ability of workers to move to different locations for employment.
The ability of workers to change between different types of jobs.
The amount of output produced per unit of input.
The amount of output produced per worker over a period of time.
The total amount of goods or services produced.
The total amount spent on new capital goods, including replacement of worn-out capital.
The loss in value of capital goods over time due to wear and tear.
Gross investment minus depreciation.
The next best alternative forgone when a choice is made.
A situation where choosing more of one thing means having less of another.
A diagram showing the maximum possible output combinations of two goods given available resources and technology.
Represents efficient use of resources, producing at maximum capacity.
Represents inefficient use of resources or underutilization.
Represents an output combination that is currently unattainable with available resources.
When the opportunity cost of producing one good in terms of another remains the same.
As production of one good increases, the opportunity cost of producing additional units rises.

The Allocation of Resources.definition: A place or system where buyers and sellers exchange goods and services.
Individuals or groups who buy goods and services for personal use.
Businesses that produce and sell goods or services.
Natural resources used to produce goods.
The willingness and ability to buy a good or service at a given price.
Demand backed by the ability to pay.
Desire for a product without the ability to pay.
When price falls, quantity demanded rises, and when price rises, quantity demanded falls, ceteris paribus.
The total quantity demanded by all consumers in a market.
An increase in quantity demanded due to a fall in price.
A decrease in quantity demanded due to a rise in price.
An increase in demand at every price level.
A decrease in demand at every price level.
Goods for which demand increases as income increases.
Goods for which demand decreases as income increases.
Goods that can replace each other in consumption.
Goods that are consumed together.
The willingness and ability of producers to sell goods or services at a given price.
Supply without the ability to actually sell the good or service.
Supply backed by the ability to produce and sell.
When price rises, quantity supplied increases, and when price falls, quantity supplied decreases, ceteris paribus.
The total quantity supplied by all producers in a market.
The quantity supplied by a single producer.
An increase in supply at every price level.
A decrease in supply at every price level.
An increase in quantity supplied due to a rise in price.
A decrease in quantity supplied due to a fall in price.
A charge imposed by the government on individuals or businesses.
A tax paid directly to the government, such as income tax.
A tax levied on goods and services, such as VAT.
A payment made by the government to encourage production or consumption of certain goods.
The point where demand equals supply in a market.
When demand and supply are not equal.
When quantity demanded exceeds quantity supplied.
When quantity supplied exceeds quantity demanded.
The way prices allocate resources through changes in demand and supply.
Allocating resources, signalling information, and rationing goods.
A measure of how responsive demand is to changes in price.
When demand changes by a larger percentage than the change in price.
When demand changes by a smaller percentage than the change in price.
When demand changes by the same percentage as the change in price.
When demand does not change at all with a change in price.
When demand changes infinitely with any change in price.
Products with close substitutes, leading to more elastic demand.
Products with few substitutes, leading to more inelastic demand.
A measure of how responsive supply is to changes in price.
When supply changes by a larger percentage than the change in price.
When supply changes by a smaller percentage than the change in price.
When supply changes by the same percentage as the change in price.
When supply does not change at all with a change in price.
When supply changes infinitely with any change in price.
An economic system where the government makes all production decisions.
An economic system where decisions are driven by supply and demand.
An economy with both government and market decision-making.
Businesses owned and operated by the government.
Orders or instructions issued, often by the government, to control economic activity.
The part of the economy owned by the government.
The part of the economy owned by individuals and businesses.
Industries that extract natural resources.
Industries that process raw materials into finished goods.
Industries that provide services.
Industries that provide knowledge-based services.
Transfer of ownership from the public sector to the private sector.
Transfer of ownership from the private sector to the public sector.
A person who benefits from a good without paying for it.
When markets fail to allocate resources efficiently.
Goods that provide benefits to society and are often under-consumed.
Goods that have negative effects on society and are often over-consumed.
Goods that are non-excludable and non-rivalrous.
When people cannot be prevented from using a good.
When one person's use of a good does not reduce its availability to others.
When people benefit from a good without contributing to its cost.
Costs borne by the producer or consumer directly involved in a transaction.
Benefits enjoyed by the producer or consumer directly involved in a transaction.
Costs imposed on third parties by economic activities.
Benefits gained by third parties from economic activities.
The total of private and external costs.
The total of private and external benefits.
Social costs minus social benefits.
Social benefits minus social costs.
The level of output where social benefits equal social costs.
When buyers or sellers lack full information, leading to poor decisions.
A market with a single seller dominating supply.
When firms agree to set prices rather than competing.
A maximum price set by the government.
A minimum price set by the government.
Illegal buying and selling of goods and services.
Focusing on immediate gains at the expense of long-term performance.
Rules set by the government to control business practices.
Industries important for a country's economy, security, or infrastructure.
Markets where a single firm can supply the entire market more efficiently than multiple firms.
Industries that are, or have potential to be world leaders.
Limits on the quantity of goods that can be imported or produced.

Microeconomics decision-makers.definition: An individual who purchases goods and services for personal use.
A person or organization that makes goods or provides services.
The quantity of a good or service consumers are willing and able to buy at different prices.
The quantity of a good or service producers are willing and able to provide at different prices.
A place or system where buyers and sellers interact to exchange goods and services.

Government and Macroeconomy.definition: Gross Domestic Product - the total value of goods and services produced in a country.
A sustained increase in the general price level of goods and services.
The situation where people willing and able to work cannot find employment.
Government policy regarding taxation and spending to influence the economy.
Central bank policy regarding money supply and interest rates to control inflation and economic growth.

Economic Development.definition: An increase in a country's real GDP over time.
The level of wealth, comfort, and material goods available to people.
A country with low levels of industrialization and income per capita.
A country with high levels of industrialization and income per capita.
A measure combining life expectancy, education, and income indicators.

International trade and globalization.definition: The increasing integration of economies, cultures, and societies worldwide.
Trade between countries without restrictions such as tariffs or quotas.
Government policies designed to protect domestic industries from foreign competition.
A country's ability to produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another country.
When a country exports more than it imports.

Business and Its Environment.definition: An organization engaged in commercial, industrial, or professional activities, producing goods or providing services to satisfy consumer needs and earn a profit, or fulfill other objectives such as social impact.
The sequence of activities where inputs (such as raw materials, labor, and capital) are converted into outputs (goods or services) that provide value to customers.
The process by which a business delivers products or services that customers perceive as more valuable than the sum of their inputs, often resulting in competitive advantage and customer loyalty.
The resources—land, labor, capital, and enterprise—used in the production of goods and services.
Natural resources used in production, including raw materials, minerals, and physical land area.
Human effort, both physical and mental, used in the production process.
Man-made resources such as machinery, buildings, and technology used in production.
The entrepreneurial skill to organize the other factors of production, take risks, and innovate in order to run a business.
The series of processes through which a product passes from raw materials to the final product delivered to consumers.
Increasing the worth of a product by enhancing its features, branding, quality, or convenience so that customers are willing to pay more than the cost of inputs.
A unique name, symbol, or design that identifies and differentiates a product or company in the marketplace.
The value of the next best alternative forgone when a choice is made.
The economic factors of supply and demand that influence prices, output, and resource allocation in a market economy.
An ever-changing set of external and internal factors—economic, social, political, technological—that influence business decisions and performance.
Enterprises operating in a small geographical area, serving the needs of the local community.
Companies that operate across an entire country but are not involved in international trade.
Firms that operate in multiple countries, engaging in trade and investment across borders.
Corporations with operations, assets, and employees in more than one country, managing production or delivering services globally.
An individual who identifies a business opportunity, organizes resources, takes risks, and innovates to establish and grow a business.
Obstacles such as lack of capital, regulatory restrictions, market competition, or cultural attitudes that hinder the creation of new businesses.
Employees who act like entrepreneurs within an organization, developing new ideas, projects, or innovations for the company.
The possibility that a company will experience lower profits or losses due to uncertainties in the market, competition, or internal operations.
Situations where the outcomes of decisions are unknown because of unpredictable changes in the environment or market conditions.
A formal written document outlining a company’s objectives, strategies, market analysis, financial projections, and operational plan.
A concise overview of the main points of a business plan, designed to quickly inform and attract potential investors or stakeholders.
The legal and organizational framework of a business, such as sole trader, partnership, or company.
The part of the economy involved in extracting and harvesting natural resources, such as farming, fishing, and mining.
The manufacturing and construction industries that process raw materials into finished goods.
The sector providing services to consumers and businesses, such as retail, healthcare, and banking.
Knowledge-based industries, including research, development, and information technology services.
Businesses owned and operated by private individuals or companies rather than the government.
Organizations and services owned and managed by the government, funded through taxation.
A business owned and run by one individual, who is personally responsible for all debts and decisions.
A business owned by two or more individuals who share profits, losses, and management responsibilities.
The ability of a business to continue operating despite changes in ownership or management.
A legal document that sets out the terms and responsibilities of each partner in a partnership.
A legal situation where business owners are personally responsible for all debts of the business.
A legal status where owners' financial responsibility is limited to their investment in the business.
A legal entity separate from its owners, which can own property, incur debt, and be sued.
Individuals or institutions that own shares in a company, representing part ownership.
Companies whose shares are privately owned and not traded on a stock exchange.
Companies whose shares can be publicly traded on a stock exchange.
A legal document that sets out the fundamental conditions under which a company operates.
The internal rulebook of a company, detailing the responsibilities of directors and procedures for managing the company.
A business arrangement where the franchisor allows a franchisee to operate using its brand, systems, and support in return for fees or royalties.
The original business owner that grants the right to operate a franchise.
An individual or business that operates a franchise under the franchisor’s brand and system.
A percentage of sales or fixed fee paid by a franchisee to a franchisor for the right to operate under its brand.
Member-owned businesses where profits and decision-making are shared among members.
A business arrangement where two or more parties agree to combine resources for a specific project or objective.
Businesses with a social or environmental mission, reinvesting profits to achieve their goals rather than maximizing shareholder value.
The process by which a private company sells shares to the public for the first time.
Firms with a limited number of employees, low revenue, and small market share, often operating locally.
Companies larger than small businesses but still below the scale of large corporations, often defined by staff numbers and turnover.
Businesses where decision-making and ownership are largely controlled by family members.
The expansion of a business in terms of sales, output, market share, or profitability.
Business expansion achieved through mergers, acquisitions, or strategic alliances.
Business expansion from within, using its own resources to increase capacity, sales, or market reach.
The joining of two companies into one, usually to achieve economies of scale or strategic benefits.
The process of combining operations of two businesses to increase efficiency or market power.
The purchase of one company by another, either through mutual agreement or a hostile bid.
Merging with or acquiring a company at the same stage of production in the same industry.
Acquiring or merging with a company closer to the final consumer in the supply chain.
Acquiring or merging with a supplier or producer of raw materials.
Agreements between businesses to collaborate and share resources without merging ownership.
Specific goals that a business aims to achieve, guiding decision-making and strategy.
The goal of achieving the highest possible financial return for owners or shareholders.
The objective of keeping the business operational, often a focus during economic downturns or start-up phases.
Expanding into new products, markets, or industries to spread risk and increase growth opportunities.
A framework for evaluating business success based on social, environmental, and financial performance.
Business goals based on moral principles, such as fairness, honesty, and environmental responsibility.
A company’s commitment to ethical practices, community engagement, and sustainable operations beyond legal requirements.
A short statement defining a company’s purpose, values, and core objectives.
An aspirational description of what a company aims to achieve in the long term.
A long-term plan to achieve business objectives, considering competitive and environmental factors.
Short-term, specific actions taken to implement a business strategy.
A financial plan outlining expected income and expenditure over a set period.
Goals that are Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound.
Individuals or groups affected by or having an interest in a business’s activities.
Stakeholders within the organization, such as employees, managers, and owners.
Stakeholders outside the organization, such as customers, suppliers, investors, and the community.
Payments made to shareholders from a company’s profits.
The idea that a company’s primary responsibility is to maximize returns for its shareholders.
The idea that a business should serve the interests of all stakeholders, not just shareholders.
A situation in which the owners of a company (shareholders) are different from those who manage it (executives), potentially leading to conflicts of interest.
A technique for identifying and analyzing stakeholders based on their level of interest and influence over business decisions.

Human Resource Management.definition: A strategic function concerned with attracting, selecting, developing, motivating, and retaining employees to achieve organisational goals. HRM aligns people policies (recruitment, training, reward, relations) with corporate strategy and legal/ethical standards.

Reducing the number of levels in an organisational hierarchy to speed decision-making, widen spans of control, lower costs, and empower front-line staff—while risking role overload and weaker supervision.
Structuring employees into groups with shared goals and interdependent tasks to improve communication, innovation, and accountability; often linked to quality circles and cross-functional squads.
Forecasting an organisation’s future people needs (numbers, skills, locations) and designing actions—hiring, upskilling, redeployment—to close gaps in the short and long run.
The rate at which employees leave and are replaced, commonly measured annually. High turnover raises recruitment/training costs and can signal morale or pay issues.
A document that states the role’s purpose, duties, reporting lines, and performance standards—used for recruitment, evaluation, and compliance.
A systematic study of a job’s tasks, responsibilities, and required competencies, producing job descriptions and person specifications.
The profile of essential and desirable candidate attributes—skills, qualifications, experience, and behaviours—used to assess applicants fairly.
A legally binding agreement detailing terms of employment (pay, hours, duties, benefits, notice, confidentiality). Sets rights/obligations for employer and employee.
The process of generating a pool of qualified applicants through methods such as adverts, agencies, referrals, or campus outreach.
Notices that market a vacancy—clarifying role, requirements, pay band, and application process—while reinforcing employer brand and legal equality standards.
Using digital platforms (ATS, job boards, social media) to reach candidates, screen applications, and schedule assessments efficiently.
Intermediaries that source, screen, and sometimes employ workers on behalf of client firms; useful for speed and scarce skills but add fees.
Filling vacancies from within via promotions/transfers. Benefits: morale, cultural fit, lower risk; risk: reduced diversity of ideas and internal ‘poaching’.
Shared values, norms, and behaviours (‘how we do things here’) that shape decisions, performance, and retention; may be clan, adhocracy, market, or hierarchy-oriented.
Filling roles from the labour market to inject new skills and perspectives; typically longer lead-times and higher onboarding needs.
Choosing the best candidate(s) using valid, reliable methods (screening, tests, interviews, assessment centres) to predict job performance and fit.
Curriculum Vitae: a detailed record of education, experience, skills, and achievements—often used in academic/international contexts.
A concise, targeted summary of skills and experience tailored to a specific role—common in North America.
Structured or semi-structured conversations to assess competence and fit; structured, competency-based interviews improve validity and fairness.
Multi-exercise evaluations (group tasks, role-plays, case studies, psychometrics) rated by multiple assessors to reduce bias and improve prediction of job success.
Ending employment because a role is no longer required (technology change, restructuring). Requires fair selection, consultation, and statutory payments where applicable.
Legal bodies that hear disputes on employment rights (unfair dismissal, discrimination, wage claims) and can award remedies/compensation.
Employees choose to leave with agreed terms; can reduce conflict and preserve morale but risks loss of key talent.
Employer-initiated exits following objective selection criteria; legally sensitive—must ensure fairness and support for leavers.
The mandated process: consultation, fair selection, notice, severance, and redeployment support; failure risks legal challenge and reputational harm.
Termination of employment due to misconduct, capability, statutory restriction, or other substantial reason—must follow fair procedure.
A dismissal with a potentially fair reason and a fair process (investigation, hearing, right of appeal) in line with law and policy.
Termination without a fair reason or due process, or for prohibited reasons (e.g., discrimination, whistleblowing), exposing the employer to legal remedy.
Collective enthusiasm and confidence of employees; high morale drives productivity, quality, and retention.
Employer initiatives that support employees’ physical, mental, and financial wellbeing—healthcare, counselling, canteens, hardship funds.
A sustainable equilibrium between job demands and personal life—supported by flexible work, reasonable hours, and leave policies.
Representation of different identities (gender, ethnicity, age, disability, orientation, background). Diverse teams improve creativity and decision quality.
Ensuring equal opportunity and fair treatment regardless of protected characteristics; requires unbiased processes and monitoring outcomes.
The organisation’s reputation as a workplace, shaped by culture, career paths, leadership, and rewards—key to attracting and retaining talent.
Planned learning to build current role skills (training) and future capabilities (development), using on-the-job, off-the-job, and digital methods.
Onboarding that introduces new hires to culture, policies, systems, and colleagues to speed up time-to-productivity and reduce early attrition.
Learning away from the workplace (courses, workshops, e-learning, simulations) to deepen knowledge with minimal day-to-day interruptions.
Learning by doing under supervision (shadowing, coaching, job rotation), embedding skills directly in work context.
Assigning authority for tasks and decisions while retaining accountability—builds capability, motivation, and managerial bandwidth.
Member-led organisations that represent workers in bargaining over pay, hours, and conditions; also support members in disputes.
Collective measures (strikes, work-to-rule, overtime bans) taken by employees to exert pressure in disputes with employers.
Negotiation between employers and unions over pay and conditions; outcomes may be firm-level or sectoral, and legally binding.
A workplace where union membership is a condition of employment; controversial and restricted/illegal in many jurisdictions.
Internal and external drivers of effort and persistence at work—intrinsic (purpose, mastery) and extrinsic (pay, recognition) factors.
Doing work for its inherent interest or satisfaction—linked to autonomy, mastery, purpose, and meaningful impact.
Effort driven by external rewards or avoidance of sanctions—pay, bonuses, status, performance ratings.
Unplanned, avoidable absence from work; high rates signal issues in wellbeing, workload, or management; managed via support and attendance policies.
Foundational requirements (physiological, safety, social, esteem, self-actualisation) that influence workplace behaviour and motivation.
Theories that identify what motivates people (e.g., Maslow, Herzberg, McClelland) rather than how motivation operates.
An approach emphasising work study, standardisation, and pay for performance to raise efficiency—criticised for ignoring human/social needs.
The phenomenon where people change behaviour because they know they are being observed; highlighted the role of attention and social factors in productivity.
A five-level model (physiological → safety → social → esteem → self-actualisation) suggesting unmet lower needs dominate motivation until satisfied.
Basic survival requirements (food, rest, pay sufficient to live). Employers address via fair wages and safe working conditions.
Safety and stability (job security, safe environment, benefits). Policies and H&S practices help satisfy these needs.
Belonging and relationships at work—team cohesion, inclusion, supportive leadership, and collaboration opportunities.
Recognition, status, responsibility, and achievement; addressed by feedback, promotions, and meaningful goals.
Realising one’s potential through challenging work, creativity, autonomy, and growth opportunities.
Distinguishes hygiene factors (pay, policies, conditions) preventing dissatisfaction from motivators (achievement, recognition, work itself) that create satisfaction.
Context elements (salary, supervision, policies, conditions) that, if poor, cause dissatisfaction but, if adequate, don’t necessarily motivate.
Content factors (achievement, recognition, responsibility, advancement) that increase intrinsic motivation and job satisfaction.
Proposes three learned motives—need for power (nPow), achievement (nAch), and affiliation (nAff)—vary by individual and shape job fit and leadership style.
Need for Power: desire to influence and impact others or outcomes; can be socialised (for the group) or personalised (self-focused).
Need for Achievement: preference for challenging goals, feedback, personal responsibility; correlates with entrepreneurial roles.
Need for Affiliation: desire for harmonious relationships and belonging; suited to team-oriented and client-facing roles.
Motivation = Expectancy (effort→performance) × Instrumentality (performance→reward) × Valence (value of reward). All three must be positive to energise effort.
Belief that effort will lead to the required performance—improved by training, clear goals, and resources.
Belief that good performance will be rewarded—strengthened by transparent, credible pay-for-performance links.
The perceived value of the reward to the individual; varies by person (e.g., cash, time off, recognition).
Fixed periodic pay (usually monthly/annual) independent of hours worked; suits professional/managerial roles.
Hourly or weekly pay based on time worked; may include overtime premiums and allowances.
Pay per unit produced; sharpens output incentives but can harm quality/safety if controls are weak.
Payment based on time worked; simple and predictable but weak link to productivity without performance metrics.
Performance-linked pay, typically a percentage of sales; aligns incentives but may encourage short-termism if poorly designed.
Lump-sum variable pay tied to objectives (individual, team, or company). Should be transparent and defensible to sustain motivation.
Distributing a portion of profits to employees to align interests and foster ownership mindset; payouts vary with company results.
Variable pay linked to appraised performance or KPIs; effectiveness hinges on fair measurement and timely feedback.
Non-cash rewards such as pensions, health insurance, canteen meals, transport, childcare, stock options, or extra leave.
Reconfiguring tasks, workflows, and autonomy to improve motivation and performance (job enrichment, enlargement, rotation).
Vertical job loading—adding responsibility, autonomy, and variety to enhance intrinsic motivation and growth.
Horizontal expansion—adding similar-level tasks to reduce monotony and improve task identity.
Planned movement across roles to broaden skills, reduce fatigue, and build succession depth.
Granting decision rights, information, and tools to employees to act with initiative; requires trust and clear boundaries.
Advancement to a higher grade, role, or pay band based on merit or potential; supports retention and succession.
Mechanisms for staff voice in decisions (works councils, suggestion schemes, surveys); enhances buy-in and change outcomes.
Planning, organising, leading, and controlling resources to achieve objectives; converts strategy into execution through people.
Classical framework: planning, organising, commanding/leading, coordinating, and controlling—foundations for modern managerial practice.

Ten roles grouped into interpersonal (figurehead, leader, liaison), informational (monitor, disseminator, spokesperson), and decisional (entrepreneur, disturbance handler, resource allocator, negotiator).
Monitoring internal/external information, disseminating insights to teams, and representing the unit/firm to stakeholders.
Acting as figurehead, leader, and liaison—motivating staff, building networks, and embodying organisational values.
Allocating resources, solving problems, driving change, and negotiating agreements under uncertainty and constraints.
Top-down decision-making with minimal consultation; clear direction and fast decisions but lower empowerment and creativity.
Managers consult and involve employees in decisions; strengthens engagement and innovation but can slow delivery.
Manager acts like a ‘parent’—makes decisions in employees’ perceived best interests while seeking loyalty; supportive but can be patronising.
Hands-off leadership granting high autonomy to capable teams; can boost creativity but risks drift without clear goals/feedback.
Assumes people dislike work and need close supervision and control; tends to use directive, tightly monitored practices.
Assumes people are self-motivated, seek responsibility, and can self-direct; favours empowerment, participation, and developmental leadership.

Marketing.definition: The process of identifying, anticipating, and satisfying customer needs profitably through creating, communicating, and delivering value.
Specific, measurable goals aligned with corporate strategy (e.g., increase market share by 5% in 12 months) guiding marketing activities.
A long-term plan to achieve marketing objectives, defining target markets, positioning, and marketing mix choices.
The quantity of a product consumers are willing and able to buy at various prices over a given period.
The quantity of a product producers are willing and able to sell at various prices over a given period.
The price and quantity at which demand equals supply, with no excess demand or supply in the market.
Marketing products or services directly to individual consumers for personal use.
Marketing products or services to other businesses for use in production or operations.
Markets serving a small, specific geographic area, often with localised products and promotion.
Markets covering an entire country, requiring broader distribution and potentially standardised products.
Markets across multiple countries, requiring adaptation for cultural, legal, and economic differences.
A business philosophy focusing on meeting customer needs and building long-term relationships.
A focus on product quality, innovation, and efficiency rather than directly addressing customer preferences.
The total sales volume or value of a market over a period, indicating potential revenue.
The rate at which total market sales are increasing over time.
Goods purchased by individuals for personal or household use.
Goods purchased by businesses for use in production or operations.
Markets for goods and services purchased by individuals for personal consumption.
Markets for goods and services purchased by organisations for operational use or resale.
A distinct feature or benefit that sets a product apart from competitors.
Targeting a small, specialised segment of the market with tailored products.
Selling a product to the whole market with little or no differentiation.
Dividing a market into distinct groups of consumers with similar needs or characteristics.
Dividing the market based on location, such as regions, cities, or climates.
Dividing the market based on demographic factors like age, gender, income, or education.
Dividing the market based on lifestyle, values, and personality traits.
Dividing the market based on buying behaviours, usage rates, or loyalty.
The ability of a business to keep customers over time through satisfaction and loyalty-building strategies.
Strategies and technologies for managing interactions with current and potential customers.
A marketing approach focused on long-term engagement and loyalty rather than one-time transactions.
The process of collecting and analysing information about markets, competitors, and customers to support decision-making.
Collecting new, original data directly from sources through surveys, interviews, or experiments.
Using existing data from published sources to inform decisions.
Collecting data by watching customer behaviours in natural settings.
Structured questionnaires used to collect information from a sample of respondents.
Launching a product in a limited area to gauge customer reaction before a full rollout.
Small, moderated discussions with target consumers to gather insights and opinions.
Employee groups meeting regularly to suggest and discuss quality improvements.
Selecting a portion of the population to represent the whole in research.
Selecting participants purely by chance to avoid bias.
Dividing the population into subgroups and sampling from each proportionally.
Sampling based on fixed quotas for specific subgroups.
Non-numerical information describing qualities or characteristics.
Numerical information that can be measured and analysed statistically.
The average value in a data set, calculated as the sum divided by the number of items.
The value that appears most frequently in a data set.
The middle value when data is arranged in order.
A measure of the spread of data around the mean.
The combination of product, price, place, and promotion strategies to meet customer needs.
The goods or services offered to meet customer needs.
The amount charged to customers for a product.
The distribution channels used to deliver a product to customers.
Activities to inform, persuade, and remind customers about a product.
Physical attributes of a product such as design, packaging, and features.
Non-physical attributes such as brand image, reputation, and service quality.
Making a product distinct from competitors through features, quality, or branding.
The stages a product goes through from introduction to decline.
The range of products offered by a business.
Assessing a firm's products to allocate resources effectively.
The first stage of the product lifecycle, when a product is launched.
The stage where sales increase rapidly as the product gains market acceptance.
Sales growth slows and competition intensifies.
Market demand peaks, and most potential customers have purchased the product.
Sales fall as demand decreases due to changing tastes or new products.
Methods to extend a product’s lifecycle, such as rebranding or targeting new markets.
Integrating products into media content for promotion.
A portfolio analysis tool categorising products as Stars, Cash Cows, Question Marks, or Dogs.
Products with high market share in low-growth markets, generating steady profits.
Products with low market share in high-growth markets, needing investment to grow or risk becoming Dogs.
Products with low market share in low-growth markets, often candidates for divestment.
Products with high market share in high-growth markets, requiring investment to maintain position.
When Question Marks become Stars, then Cash Cows, delivering long-term profitability.
When products fail to grow and move from Question Marks to Dogs.
Maximising short-term profits from a product before withdrawing it.
Selling or phasing out a product to free resources.
Setting price by adding a markup to the cost of production.
Charging a high price initially, then lowering it over time to capture different market segments.
Setting a low initial price to quickly gain market share.
Charging different prices to different customers for the same product.
Setting prices based on competitors’ pricing strategies.
Adjusting prices in real time based on demand, competition, or other factors.
Setting prices that have a psychological impact, such as £9.99 instead of £10.
The blend of promotional tools (advertising, sales promotion, personal selling, PR, direct marketing) used to achieve objectives.
Paid, non-personal communication to promote products, brands, or ideas.
Providing factual details to increase awareness and understanding of a product.
Aiming to influence consumer attitudes and persuade purchase.
Short-term incentives to encourage purchases, such as discounts or free samples.
Face-to-face interaction with potential buyers to persuade them to purchase.
Communicating directly with customers through methods like direct mail or telemarketing.
Sending promotional messages to customers via email.
Creating a distinctive identity for a product or company.
The perception and associations customers have with a brand.
The design and function of a product’s container, influencing appeal and protection.
The percentage of people who click on a digital ad or link after seeing it.
The average cost of gaining a new customer.
The routes through which a product is distributed to customers.
Firms or individuals involved in moving products from producer to consumer.
Buying and selling goods or services online.
A physical or online location where customers can purchase products.

Operations Management.definition: The administration of business practices to efficiently convert inputs (materials, labor, capital) into outputs (goods and services) while meeting quality, cost, and delivery targets.
The stock of raw materials, work-in-progress, and finished goods that a business holds to meet production and customer demand.
The ability to produce the maximum output from the minimum input, reducing waste and cost.
The degree to which operations achieve intended goals, such as meeting customer requirements or production targets.
The ratio of output produced to the inputs used, often measured as output per worker or per hour.
Operating in a way that meets current needs without compromising future resources, balancing environmental, social, and economic factors.
The network of organisations, people, activities, and resources involved in producing and delivering a product from suppliers to end customers.
Production processes that require high investment in machinery and equipment relative to labor.
Production processes that rely more heavily on human labor than machinery.
Producing unique, customised products one at a time to meet specific customer orders.
Producing a limited quantity of identical items in a group before switching to another product.
Continuous production where items move through the production process without interruption.
Using flexible production systems to produce goods tailored to individual customer requirements on a large scale.
Extra stock kept to protect against unexpected demand or supply delays.
The stock level at which a new order should be placed to avoid running out.
The time taken between placing an order and receiving the goods.
Visual tools showing stock levels, reorder points, and buffer stock to manage inventory effectively.
The optimal order quantity that minimises the total costs of ordering and holding inventory.
The total costs of holding inventory, including storage, insurance, depreciation, and obsolescence.
The costs associated with placing and receiving orders, including administration and delivery fees.
The planning, coordination, and optimisation of supply chain activities to improve efficiency, responsiveness, and customer satisfaction.
An inventory system where materials arrive exactly when needed in production, reducing storage costs.
An inventory system where businesses keep extra stock to avoid running out during demand or supply uncertainties.
The percentage of a firm's total production capacity that is actually being used.
Operating beyond the optimal capacity, often leading to inefficiency and strain on resources.
Operating below optimal capacity, resulting in underused resources and higher unit costs.
Contracting out certain business processes to external suppliers to reduce costs or improve efficiency.
Hiring another firm to complete part of a project or production process.
Streamlining operations by closing inefficient facilities, cutting costs, and focusing on core activities.

Finance.definition: The management of money and other assets, including planning, raising, investing, and controlling funds to achieve business objectives.
Resources owned by a business that have economic value and can be converted into cash or used to generate income.
Funds provided for investment in a business, either by owners (equity) or lenders (debt).
The initial funding required to start a business, covering expenses such as equipment, licensing, and initial inventory.
The difference between current assets and current liabilities, indicating liquidity and operational efficiency.
Long-term resources such as property, plant, and equipment that a business uses over several years.
Short-term assets expected to be converted into cash or used up within a year, such as inventory and receivables.
Obligations a business owes to external parties, including debts, loans, and accounts payable.
Debts or obligations due within one year, such as trade payables and short-term loans.
Long-term debts or obligations not due within the next year, such as mortgages and bonds.
Funding methods with repayment periods under a year, like overdrafts, trade credit, and factoring.
Funding with repayment terms over a year, such as equity capital, bonds, and long-term loans.
A financial state where liabilities exceed assets, and the business cannot meet its debt obligations.
The process of selling all assets to pay creditors before closing the business.
A legal process where an insolvent business or individual is declared unable to repay debts.
A legal process where an external administrator is appointed to manage an insolvent business and protect it from creditors.
Amounts a business owes to suppliers for goods or services purchased on credit.
Amounts owed to a business by customers who have purchased goods or services on credit.
The time taken to convert resource inputs into cash flows from sales, factoring in inventory turnover, receivables, and payables.
Spending on day-to-day operations and maintenance rather than long-term assets.
Spending on acquiring, upgrading, or extending the life of fixed assets.
A financial report (balance sheet) showing a company’s assets, liabilities, and equity at a specific date.
A financial report (income statement) showing revenues, expenses, and profit over a period.
Funds generated from within the business, such as retained earnings or asset sales.
Funds obtained from outside the business, such as bank loans, investors, or grants.
An arrangement where suppliers allow a business to pay for goods or services after delivery.
Selling an asset to a buyer and leasing it back to free up capital while retaining use.
Profits reinvested into the business rather than distributed to shareholders as dividends.
Renting an asset from the owner for a fixed period instead of purchasing it.
Funds raised by issuing shares to investors in exchange for ownership in the company.
A method of buying assets by paying in installments, with ownership transferred after the final payment.
Borrowed funds from a bank, usually repaid with interest over a set period.
Long-term debt instruments used by companies to borrow money at a fixed interest rate.
Long-term loans secured against property or land.
Selling accounts receivable to a third party (factor) at a discount for immediate cash.
Investment from firms or individuals in high-growth startups in exchange for equity.
Raising small amounts of money from a large number of people, typically via online platforms.
Providing small loans to low-income individuals or small businesses without access to traditional banking.
A financial ratio measuring a company’s leverage by comparing total debt to total equity.
A projection of future cash inflows and outflows to assess liquidity needs.
Money received by a business from sales, loans, investments, or other sources.
Money spent by a business on expenses, investments, or debt repayment.
The difference between total cash inflows and total cash outflows in a period.
Expenses incurred in the process of producing and selling goods or services.
Income generated from the sale of goods or services before expenses are deducted.
Costs that do not change with production levels, such as rent or salaries.
Costs that vary directly with production levels, such as raw materials.
The sum of fixed and variable costs for a given level of production.
The level of sales at which total revenue equals total cost, resulting in zero profit.
The amount by which actual or forecasted sales exceed the breakeven point.
Costs that can be directly attributed to the production of specific goods or services.
Overhead costs that cannot be directly linked to specific products, such as utilities.
A costing method that allocates all fixed and variable costs to products.
A department or unit within an organisation responsible for controlling costs.
A business unit responsible for generating revenue and controlling costs.
A costing method focusing on the contribution margin, calculated as sales revenue minus variable costs.
Financial plans outlining expected income and expenses for a set period.
Budgeting based on the previous year’s figures plus or minus an incremental amount.
Budgeting where each expense must be justified from scratch, regardless of past budgets.
Budgets that can adjust to changes in activity levels or conditions.
The difference between budgeted and actual performance.
When actual results are better than budgeted, such as higher revenue or lower costs.
When actual results are worse than budgeted, such as lower revenue or higher costs.

Basic Economic Ideas and Resource Alloca.definition: The issue of scarcity arising because resources are limited while human wants are unlimited, requiring choices about the allocation of resources.
Desires for goods and services that improve quality of life but are not necessary for survival, such as vacations or luxury clothing.
Essential goods and services required for basic human survival and well-being, such as food, shelter, and water.
The four inputs used to produce goods and services: land, labour, capital, and enterprise.
Natural resources used in production, including soil, minerals, forests, and bodies of water.
The physical and mental human effort used in the production process.
Man-made resources such as machinery, tools, and infrastructure used to produce goods and services.
The human skill and risk-taking ability involved in organizing the other factors of production to create goods and services.
The payment received for the use of a factor of production: rent for land, wages for labour, interest for capital, and profit for enterprise.
The value of the next best alternative that must be given up when a choice is made.
A compromise where gaining more of one thing means having less of another due to resource constraints.
The study of economic facts and cause-and-effect relationships without making value judgments.
The branch of economics that involves value judgments and opinions about what the economy should be like.
A graph showing the maximum possible combinations of two goods or services that can be produced using all resources efficiently.
The rate at which the production of one good must decrease to increase the production of another good, represented by the slope of the PPC.
The principle that producing more of one good requires giving up increasingly larger amounts of another good due to resource specialization.
A situation in which producing more of one good requires giving up progressively smaller amounts of another good.
Technological progress that disproportionately benefits the production of one type of good over another.
Technological improvement that enhances the production of all goods equally.
Physical, tangible items that satisfy human wants and needs, such as cars or books.
Intangible activities or benefits provided to satisfy needs and wants, such as education or healthcare.
Goods that are not scarce and are available without opportunity cost, such as air in most situations.
Goods that are scarce and require resources to produce, involving an opportunity cost.
Goods that are non-excludable and non-rivalrous, such as national defense or street lighting.
Goods that are excludable and rivalrous, meaning consumption by one person reduces availability for others.
A property of a good where people can be prevented from using it if they do not pay.
A property of a good where consumption by one person reduces the amount available for others.
A situation in which individuals benefit from a good without contributing to its cost, common with public goods.
An economic system where the government makes all decisions about resource allocation and production.
An economic system where decisions on production and consumption are made by private individuals through market forces.
An economic system combining elements of market and planned economies, involving both private and public sectors.
An economic ideology where resources are collectively owned and distributed to promote equality.
An economic system based on private ownership of resources and the pursuit of profit.
Fairness in the distribution of resources and opportunities.
The optimal use of resources to maximize output and minimize waste.
Adam Smith’s concept that individuals seeking self-interest in markets inadvertently benefit society as a whole.
The process by which prices adjust to balance supply and demand in a market economy.
Economic choices made by comparing the additional benefits and costs of small changes in activity.
The core economic questions of what to produce, how to produce, and for whom to produce.
The idea that consumer preferences ultimately determine the allocation of resources in a market economy.
Countries moving from centrally planned systems to more market-oriented economies.
A time period in which at least one factor of production is fixed.
A time period in which all factors of production can be varied.
A time horizon in which technological change and population growth can alter production capacity.
Represents efficient use of resources where maximum output is achieved.
Represents underutilization or inefficiency in resource use.
Represents an unattainable level of production with current resources and technology.
The depreciation or wearing out of capital goods over time.
Total spending on new capital goods, without accounting for depreciation.
Gross investment minus depreciation, representing the actual increase in productive capacity.
The part of the economy concerned with extraction of natural resources, such as agriculture and mining.
The part of the economy involved in manufacturing and processing raw materials into finished goods.
The part of the economy providing services rather than goods, such as retail or banking.
The part of the economy focused on knowledge-based services, such as research and development.
Goods that have some characteristics of public goods but can be excludable under certain conditions, such as toll roads.

The price system and microeconomy.definition: The quantity of a good or service consumers are willing and able to purchase at various prices during a given period.
Demand backed by the ability and willingness to pay for a good or service.
Desire for a good or service that is not supported by the ability or willingness to pay.
The principle that, ceteris paribus, as the price of a good falls, the quantity demanded increases, and vice versa.
External influences on demand or supply that come from outside the market system, such as natural disasters or policy changes.
Factors that originate within the market system itself, such as consumer preferences or production costs.
An increase in quantity demanded due to a fall in the price of a good, represented by movement along the demand curve.
An increase in demand at all price levels, shown by a rightward shift of the demand curve.
A decrease in quantity demanded due to a rise in the price of a good, represented by movement along the demand curve.
A decrease in demand at all price levels, shown by a leftward shift of the demand curve.
The total demand for a product from all consumers in a market.
The quantity of a good or service demanded by a single consumer at various prices.
A Latin phrase meaning 'all other things being equal', used to isolate the effect of one variable in economic analysis.
The quantity of a good or service that producers are willing and able to sell at various prices during a given period.
Supply that is backed by the ability and willingness of producers to sell goods or services.
When producers are willing to sell but are unable to supply goods or services due to constraints.
An increase in quantity supplied due to a rise in the price of a good, represented by movement along the supply curve.
An increase in supply at all price levels, shown by a rightward shift of the supply curve.
A decrease in quantity supplied due to a fall in the price of a good, represented by movement along the supply curve.
A decrease in supply at all price levels, shown by a leftward shift of the supply curve.
Goods for which demand decreases as consumer income rises.
Goods for which demand increases as consumer income rises.
Luxury goods for which demand increases as price rises, due to their status appeal.
