Inferior goods for which demand rises as price rises due to the strong income effect outweighing the substitution effect.
The principle that, ceteris paribus, as the price of a good rises, the quantity supplied increases, and vice versa.
Goods that are typically consumed together, so an increase in the price of one decreases demand for the other.
Goods that can replace each other in consumption, so an increase in the price of one increases demand for the other.
Goods that are produced together, so an increase in the supply of one increases the supply of the other.
Demand for a factor of production or intermediate good that arises from the demand for a final good.
The quantity of a good supplied by a single producer at various prices.
The total quantity of a good supplied by all producers in a market.
The point at which the quantity demanded equals the quantity supplied at a certain price.
The price at which market equilibrium occurs, with no surplus or shortage.
A situation where supply and demand are not balanced, causing a surplus or shortage.
When the quantity supplied exceeds the quantity demanded at the current price.
When the quantity demanded exceeds the quantity supplied at the current price.
A process where multiple buyers compete to purchase a good or service, driving up the price.
Any arrangement that allows buyers and sellers to exchange goods, services, or resources.
The system in which prices adjust to allocate resources and balance supply and demand.
The use of prices to limit demand when supply is scarce.
The process by which prices communicate information to buyers and sellers about market conditions.
The use of prices to encourage producers or consumers to act in certain ways.
The distribution of scarce resources among competing uses through market prices.
The assumption that economic agents aim to achieve the highest possible benefit from their actions.
A measure of the responsiveness of quantity demanded to a change in price.
When the percentage change in quantity demanded is greater than the percentage change in price.
When the percentage change in quantity demanded is less than the percentage change in price.
When quantity demanded changes infinitely with even the smallest change in price.
When quantity demanded remains constant regardless of price changes.
When the percentage change in quantity demanded equals the percentage change in price.
Refers to defining a good or market category in a wide sense, which typically reduces measured elasticity.
Refers to defining a good or market category in a narrow sense, which typically increases measured elasticity.
The total amount of money received by a firm from sales, calculated as price times quantity sold.

The price system and microeconomy.term: PED along a Straight Line Demand Curve
The price system and microeconomy.definition: The observation that elasticity varies along a straight-line demand curve, being elastic at higher prices and inelastic at lower prices.
A measure of the responsiveness of quantity supplied to a change in price.
When the percentage change in quantity supplied is greater than the percentage change in price.
When the percentage change in quantity supplied is less than the percentage change in price.
When quantity supplied remains constant regardless of price changes.
When quantity supplied changes infinitely with even the smallest change in price.
When the percentage change in quantity supplied equals the percentage change in price.
The visual interpretation of elasticity of supply on a graph, depending on the supply curve’s slope and position.
A measure of the responsiveness of quantity demanded to a change in consumer income.
A curve showing the relationship between income changes and the quantity of goods consumed.
When demand increases as income increases, characteristic of normal goods.
When demand decreases as income increases, characteristic of inferior goods.
When changes in income have no effect on the demand for a good.
A measure of the responsiveness of demand for one good to a change in the price of another good.
When an increase in the price of one good increases demand for another good, indicating substitutes.
When an increase in the price of one good decreases demand for another good, indicating complements.
When a change in the price of one good has no effect on the demand for another good.

Government Microeconomic Intervention.definition: The difference between the maximum price a consumer is willing to pay and the actual market price paid.
The difference between the market price received by producers and the minimum price they are willing to accept.
The sum of consumer surplus and producer surplus, representing total welfare in a market.
The loss of economic efficiency that occurs when the equilibrium outcome is not achieved, often due to market distortions.
A tax imposed on goods and services rather than on income or profits, paid indirectly by consumers via producers.
A fixed amount of tax charged per unit of a good, regardless of its price.
A tax calculated as a percentage of the selling price of a good or service.
A payment made by the government to encourage production or consumption of a good or service.
A fixed amount of financial support per unit of a good or service provided by the government.
A subsidy calculated as a percentage of the price of a good or service.
A legally imposed price ceiling above which a good or service cannot be sold.
A legally imposed price floor below which a good or service cannot be sold.
The expenses incurred in monitoring and enforcing compliance with market regulations.
Illegal markets where goods and services are traded at prices or in quantities that violate legal restrictions.
A system in which the government buys and stores surplus production in times of excess supply and releases it during shortages to stabilize prices.
Payments made by the government to individuals without any exchange of goods or services, such as welfare benefits or pensions.
A price ceiling set below the equilibrium price, causing shortages.
A price ceiling set above the equilibrium price, having no impact on the market.
A price floor set above the equilibrium price, leading to surpluses.
A price floor set below the equilibrium price, having no effect on the market.
The transfer of ownership of a business or industry from the public sector to the private sector.
The removal or reduction of government rules and regulations in an industry to encourage competition and efficiency.
The transfer of ownership of a business or industry from the private sector to the public sector.
Industries where a single firm can supply the entire market at a lower cost than multiple competing firms, often due to high fixed costs.

The macroeconomy.definition: A measure of income or wealth inequality within a population, ranging from 0 (perfect equality) to 1 (perfect inequality).
The idea that income represents the flow of money received over a period of time, such as wages, rents, and profits.
The total value of assets owned at a specific point in time, minus liabilities.
The total value of all goods and services produced in an economy over a specific period, adjusted for inflation.
Gross Domestic Product — the total market value of all final goods and services produced within a country in a given time period.
Gross National Income — GDP plus net income from abroad.
Net National Income — GNI minus depreciation of the nation’s capital goods.
Net Domestic Product — GDP minus depreciation of capital assets.
GDP calculated using the prices actually paid in the market, including taxes and excluding subsidies.
GDP calculated based on the cost of factors of production, excluding taxes and including subsidies.
A model showing the movement of goods, services, and money between households, firms, and the government.
Flows of income leaving the circular flow, such as savings, taxes, and imports.
Flows of income entering the circular flow, such as investment, government spending, and exports.
The level of income at which total injections equal total leakages.
A situation where injections and leakages are not equal, causing changes in national output and income.
The total demand for goods and services in an economy at a given overall price level and in a given time period.
Consumption, investment, government spending, and net exports (exports minus imports).
Due to the wealth effect, interest rate effect, and net export effect as prices fall.
The total quantity of goods and services that firms are willing and able to produce in an economy at a given price level.

The macroeconomy.term: Neoclassical View of LR Aggregate Supply
The macroeconomy.definition: The belief that in the long run, the economy operates at full employment and output is determined by supply-side factors.
A model suggesting that the economy can be below full employment for extended periods and government intervention may be necessary.
An increase in the output of goods and services in an economy over time.
GDP measured at current market prices, without adjusting for inflation.
GDP adjusted for changes in the price level, reflecting actual output.
A period of negative economic growth lasting at least two consecutive quarters.
A period of rapid economic growth, often leading to inflationary pressures.
A prolonged period of low economic activity and high unemployment.
The number of people willing and able to work who do not have a job.
Unemployment caused by a downturn in the economic cycle.
Short-term unemployment that occurs when people are between jobs or entering the labor force.
Unemployment linked to seasonal variations in demand or production.
Unemployment caused by automation and technological advancements replacing human labor.
People who have stopped looking for work because they believe no jobs are available for them.
Individuals engaged in unpaid domestic work, excluded from official labor force statistics.
A measure of unemployment based on the number of people claiming unemployment-related benefits.
International Labour Organization measure of unemployment based on surveys rather than benefit claims.
When workers are employed in jobs that do not fully utilize their skills or when they work fewer hours than they would like.
The tendency for unemployment to remain high even after the initial causes of unemployment have been removed.
Consumer Price Index — a measure of the average change in prices paid by consumers for goods and services over time.
A sustained increase in the general price level of goods and services in an economy.
A sustained decrease in the general price level of goods and services.
A fall in the rate of inflation, meaning prices are rising more slowly.
A distortion in CPI measurement when consumers substitute cheaper goods for more expensive ones.
Income adjusted for changes in the price level, reflecting purchasing power.
Income measured in current money terms without adjusting for inflation.
The tendency for tax revenues to rise as incomes grow, even without changes in tax rates, due to progressive taxation.
When people mistake nominal changes in wages or income for real changes.
A cycle in which wages increase, leading to higher production costs and higher prices, which in turn prompts further wage demands.
Unemployment that is not reflected in official statistics, often due to discouraged workers or involuntary part-time work.
The level of employment where only natural unemployment exists, with no cyclical unemployment.
Unemployment occurring when individuals choose not to work at the prevailing wage rate.
Unemployment where people are willing to work at the current wage rate but cannot find jobs.
Unemployment caused by wages being set above the equilibrium level.
The idea that unemployment can arise from a mismatch between workers' skills and available jobs.
Moderate inflation, typically between 3% and 10% per year, which may start to impact purchasing power.
Extremely rapid and out-of-control price increases, often exceeding 50% per month.
Slow, gradual inflation of 1–3% per year.
The quantity of goods and services that can be bought with a unit of currency.
A fixed set of consumer products and services used to track inflation over time.
Statistical measures used to show changes in a variable or group of variables over time.
The year against which other years’ economic data are compared when constructing index numbers.
Inflation caused by aggregate demand rising faster than aggregate supply.
Inflation caused by rising production costs, such as wages or raw materials.
Inflation driven by businesses and consumers expecting prices to rise, leading to behaviors that cause actual inflation.
Inflation resulting from an excessive growth in the money supply.
An equation linking nominal interest rates, real interest rates, and inflation: Nominal = Real + Inflation.
The cost of time and effort spent trying to counteract the effects of inflation, such as reducing cash holdings.
The costs incurred by firms when they change prices, such as printing new menus or price lists.
The way inflation can transfer purchasing power from lenders to borrowers or between different income groups.

Government Macroeconomic Intervention.definition: The main goals pursued by governments to promote economic stability and growth, typically including low inflation, low unemployment, economic growth, balance of payments stability, and equitable income distribution.
The use of government spending and taxation to influence the level of economic activity.
A statement of a government's expected revenue and expenditure for a specific period, usually a year.
When a government's expenditure exceeds its revenue in a given period.
When a government's revenue exceeds its expenditure in a given period.
Government spending on the day-to-day running of public services, such as wages and consumables.
Government spending on investment in long-term assets such as infrastructure, schools, and hospitals.
Payments made by the government to individuals without any goods or services being received in return, such as pensions and unemployment benefits.
Government income from sources other than taxes, such as fees, fines, and profits from state-owned enterprises.
A fiscal or monetary policy aimed at reducing aggregate demand to control inflation.
A fiscal or monetary policy aimed at increasing aggregate demand to boost economic growth.
A budget where government revenue is equal to expenditure, having no net effect on aggregate demand.
A measure of a country's government debt compared to its GDP, indicating the size of debt relative to the economy.
When a government's capital expenditure exceeds its capital revenue in a given period.
When a government's current expenditure exceeds its current revenue.
When the total government expenditure exceeds total revenue excluding borrowing.
The payment of interest and principal on outstanding government debt.
The process by which a central bank controls the money supply and interest rates to achieve macroeconomic objectives.
The cost of borrowing or the reward for saving, expressed as a percentage of the amount borrowed or saved.
The total amount of money circulating in an economy at a given time.
A policy that increases the money supply and lowers interest rates to stimulate economic activity.
A policy that reduces the money supply and raises interest rates to control inflation.
Government measures aimed at increasing the productive capacity of the economy by improving the efficiency of markets and labor productivity.

International Economic Issues.definition: The exchange of goods and services between countries, enabling nations to obtain products they cannot produce efficiently themselves.
The concentration of a country's or firm's production on a limited range of goods or services to gain efficiency and comparative advantage.
International trade conducted without tariffs, quotas, or other restrictions.
The process of reducing or eliminating barriers to trade, such as tariffs and quotas.
A curve that shows the combinations of goods an economy can consume with trade compared to without trade.
The ratio of a country's export prices to its import prices, indicating the amount of imports obtainable per unit of exports.
The ability of a country to produce a good more efficiently than another country using the same amount of resources.
The ability of a country to produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another country.
A situation in which countries involved in trade gain by specializing and exchanging goods in which they have a comparative advantage.
The use of government policies to restrict international trade and protect domestic industries from foreign competition.
Taxes imposed on imported goods to make them more expensive and protect domestic industries.
Limits on the quantity of a particular good that can be imported within a given time period.
Government payments to domestic producers to encourage exports by lowering their costs.
Government-imposed bans on trade with a particular country or in particular goods.
Excessive bureaucracy or restrictive regulations that make trade more difficult.
Selling goods in a foreign market at below the cost of production or below domestic prices to gain market share.
New and emerging industries that may need temporary protection from foreign competition to develop.
Industries experiencing long-term demand reduction, often leading to government intervention for support or retraining.
The justification for protecting industries vital to national security or economic stability.
A component of the balance of payments that records a country's trade in goods, services, primary income, and secondary income.
The value of physical products exported and imported by a country.
The value of services exported and imported, such as tourism, banking, and consultancy.
Earnings from investments and employment abroad, such as interest, dividends, and wages.
Transfers between countries, such as foreign aid, remittances, and pensions.
When a country's imports of goods, services, and incomes exceed its exports.
When a country's exports of goods, services, and incomes exceed its imports.
The difference between the value of goods a country exports and imports.
The difference between the value of services a country exports and imports.

International Economic Issues.term: Balance of Trade in Goods and Services
International Economic Issues.definition: The combined difference between a country's exports and imports of goods and services.
The net flow of goods, services, and incomes into or out of a country.
The value of one currency expressed in terms of another currency.
An exchange rate determined by market forces of supply and demand without direct government control.
An increase in the value of a currency relative to another currency.
A decrease in the value of a currency relative to another currency.
The difference in inflation rates between two countries, affecting exchange rate movements.
The movement of funds between countries to take advantage of interest rate changes and exchange rate movements.
Buying and selling currencies or assets with the aim of making a profit from future price changes.
Policies aimed at shifting spending from foreign goods to domestic goods, often through exchange rate changes or tariffs.
Policies aimed at reducing overall spending in the economy to correct a current account deficit.
Measures taken by a government to regulate or restrict capital flows into and out of the country.
Foreign currency holdings maintained by a country's central bank to influence exchange rates and maintain stability.

External Influences on Business Activity.definition: A constantly changing set of external and internal factors—such as political, economic, social, technological, environmental, and legal influences—that affect how businesses operate and compete.
The impact of government policies, legislation, political stability, and international relations on business operations and strategic decisions.
The transfer of ownership of enterprises or assets from the public sector (government) to private individuals or companies to encourage efficiency and competition.
The process by which the government takes ownership and control of private-sector industries, often for strategic, economic, or social reasons.
Regulations that govern fair treatment of employees, including hiring, dismissal, wages, working hours, and workplace safety.
The environment, safety standards, and overall circumstances in which employees perform their jobs, including physical, social, and contractual aspects.
Laws that establish the lowest legal amount an employer can pay workers per hour of labor to ensure fair compensation.
Legal measures designed to safeguard buyers from unfair business practices, defective products, and false advertising.
Regulations that prohibit businesses from making false or misleading claims about goods and services.
Collusion between businesses to fix prices, limit production, or divide markets to restrict competition.
A situation where a business controls a large share of the market, allowing it to influence prices, supply, and competition.
The actions of a single seller dominating a market, often leading to reduced competition and potential consumer harm.
Legislation aimed at preventing anti-competitive behavior, monopolies, and unfair trade practices.
The overall functioning and performance of an economy, including indicators such as GDP, unemployment, and inflation.
The sustained increase in the general price level of goods and services over time, reducing the purchasing power of money.
The percentage of the labor force that is willing and able to work but is unable to find employment.
An increase in a country's output of goods and services, measured by GDP growth over time.
A period of declining economic activity across the economy, lasting at least two consecutive quarters.
A prolonged and severe downturn in economic activity, often with high unemployment and low investment.
Government measures aimed at improving the efficiency and productivity of the economy by enhancing the supply of goods and services.
Government use of taxation and spending to influence economic activity, growth, and stability.
Central bank actions to control the money supply and interest rates to achieve economic objectives such as inflation control and growth.
A sustained decrease in the general price level of goods and services, often linked to reduced demand and economic slowdown.
An increase in the value of one country's currency relative to another, making imports cheaper and exports less competitive.
A decrease in the value of a country's currency relative to another, making exports cheaper and imports more expensive.
Joblessness caused by mismatches between workers’ skills and available jobs, often due to technological or industrial changes.
Unemployment caused by downturns in the business cycle, with reduced demand for goods and services.
Short-term unemployment occurring when individuals are between jobs or entering the labor force for the first time.
A deliberate increase in the value of a country's currency in a fixed or pegged exchange rate system.
A deliberate reduction in the value of a country's currency in a fixed or pegged exchange rate system.
The effect of societal trends, cultural norms, and values on business practices and consumer behavior.
The impact of population characteristics—such as age, gender, and migration—on market demand and labor supply.
An assessment of a company’s performance in fulfilling its social responsibilities and commitments.
An evaluation of a company's compliance with environmental laws and its impact on sustainability.
The introduction of new or significantly improved goods or services to meet consumer needs and gain competitive advantage.
The implementation of new or significantly improved production or delivery methods to enhance efficiency and quality.
Organized groups that seek to influence government policy or business practices without seeking political office.
Corporate Social Responsibility—business practices that go beyond profit-making to consider social and environmental well-being.
Business activities that meet current needs without compromising the ability of future generations to meet theirs.
Superficial actions by businesses to appear more ethical or successful than they truly are.
Misleading claims by companies about the environmental benefits of their products or practices.
When companies publicly support certain social causes while ignoring others, often based on marketing benefits.
Large volumes of complex data that businesses analyze to improve decision-making, efficiency, and customer targeting.
The use of computer systems capable of learning, adapting, and making decisions without explicit human programming.
Computer-Aided Design—software used to create precision drawings and technical illustrations in product development.
Computer-Aided Manufacturing—software and systems that control machinery and automate production processes.
Obstacles that make it difficult for new businesses to enter a market, such as high costs, regulations, or established competitors.
The competitive benefit gained by being the first company to enter a market or develop a new product.
A technological or business model breakthrough that significantly alters industries and displaces established competitors.
A legal right granted to an inventor to exclusively produce, use, and sell an invention for a set period.
The degree to which a country engages in international trade relative to the size of its economy.
A decentralized digital ledger system that records transactions securely and transparently.
Multinational Corporations—companies that operate in multiple countries, often with global supply chains and diverse markets.

Strategic Business Management.definition: The process of formulating, implementing, and evaluating cross-functional decisions that enable an organization to achieve its long-term objectives in a changing environment.
The assessment of an organization’s external environment and internal capabilities to identify opportunities, threats, strengths, and weaknesses for informed decision-making.
The process of selecting the most appropriate strategy from available alternatives to achieve organizational objectives.
The process of putting chosen strategies into action through resource allocation, organizational restructuring, and operational execution.
A concise declaration of an organization’s core purpose, values, and reason for existence.
A forward-looking declaration that outlines the desired future position or direction of the organization.
A long-term plan designed to achieve specific organizational objectives, often involving resource allocation and competitive positioning.
Short-term, specific actions undertaken to achieve strategic goals efficiently.
A business approach that focuses on creating uncontested market space and making competition irrelevant through innovation.
A competitive strategy in established markets where companies fight for market share, often leading to price wars and margin erosion.
The simultaneous pursuit of differentiation and low cost to create new market demand.
A Blue Ocean tool that asks four key questions—eliminate, reduce, raise, and create—to redesign value propositions.
A strategic framework for analyzing Political, Economic, Social, and Technological external factors affecting an organization.
A tool for identifying an organization's Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats to guide strategic planning.
A technique used to envision and prepare for multiple possible future environments and outcomes.
An extension of SWOT analysis that matches external opportunities and threats with internal strengths and weaknesses to generate strategies.
A portfolio analysis tool that classifies business units or products into Stars, Cash Cows, Question Marks, and Dogs based on market share and market growth.
A framework for assessing industry attractiveness by analyzing five competitive forces: threat of new entrants, threat of substitutes, buyer power, supplier power, and competitive rivalry.
The degree to which customers can influence prices and terms in a market.
The risk posed by new competitors entering a market and increasing competition.
The extent to which alternative products or services can replace existing offerings and reduce demand.
The ability of suppliers to influence prices, quality, and availability of inputs.
A decision-making tool that identifies and weighs driving and restraining forces affecting change.
Factors that hinder or resist change within an organization.
Factors that promote or support change within an organization.
A graphical method for evaluating decision options and their possible outcomes, including risks, rewards, and probabilities.
The weighted average of all possible outcomes, calculated by multiplying each outcome by its probability.
A financial measure of the average expected outcome of a decision based on probabilities and monetary results.
The potential gains or losses associated with a decision outcome.
Unique strengths that provide a competitive advantage and are difficult for competitors to imitate.
The essential products that directly leverage an organization’s core competencies.
Comprehensive long-term plans that guide the overall direction of an organization.
The shared values, beliefs, and norms that shape how members of an organization interact and work.
An organizational culture where individuals are prioritized over the organization, common in professional partnerships.
A structured organizational culture defined by clearly assigned roles, rules, and procedures.
A flexible culture that prioritizes teamwork and problem-solving to achieve specific goals.
A culture where decision-making authority is concentrated in a small group or a single leader.
A leadership style that inspires and motivates employees to innovate and achieve exceptional results through vision and personal influence.
Individuals who actively promote, support, and drive a project to success within the organization.
The structured approach to transitioning individuals, teams, and organizations from a current state to a desired future state.
The reluctance or refusal of individuals or groups to adapt to organizational changes.
The tendency of an organization to resist change and maintain existing structures and processes.
The identification, preparation, and response to unexpected events that threaten an organization’s survival.
Developing alternative action plans to be implemented in response to unforeseen events or disruptions.

Human Resource Management.definition: The formal system that defines how tasks, responsibilities, and authority are distributed and coordinated within an organization to achieve its objectives.
A visual diagram showing the hierarchy, reporting relationships, and departmental divisions within an organization.
The legitimate power granted to individuals or positions to make decisions, allocate resources, and direct others.
The obligation to perform assigned duties and be accountable for the outcomes.
An arrangement where the organization is divided into departments based on specialized functions such as marketing, finance, or operations.
A traditional chain-of-command structure where authority flows from top management down to lower levels.
An organizational design where divisions are formed based on specific products or product lines.
An arrangement where the organization is divided into units based on geographical regions or territories.
A hybrid structure combining functional and project-based divisions, where employees report to multiple managers.
A structure where divisions are organized around different customer segments or markets.
The process of giving employees greater authority, autonomy, and responsibility in decision-making.
The line of authority that connects each individual to the person to whom they report.
The number of subordinates directly managed by a single supervisor or manager.
The process of reducing the number of levels in an organization’s hierarchy to improve communication and decision-making.
A structure where decision-making authority is concentrated at the top levels of management.
The distribution of decision-making authority to lower levels within the organization.
The process of capturing, distributing, and effectively using organizational knowledge and expertise.
Managers who have direct responsibility for achieving organizational goals and managing frontline employees.
Managers who provide specialized advice, support, and services to line managers but do not have direct authority over core operations.
The process of transmitting information, ideas, and feelings between individuals or groups.
Information given about performance or behavior to help guide future actions.
Communication that ensures the message is clearly understood by all parties as intended.
A communication process where information flows in only one direction without feedback.
An interactive communication process that allows for feedback and discussion.
Structured communication that follows official organizational channels.
Unstructured and unofficial communication, often occurring spontaneously between employees.
The exchange of information within the organization among employees, teams, and departments.
Information exchange between the organization and external stakeholders such as customers, suppliers, and investors.
Communication that flows up or down the organizational hierarchy.
Communication between individuals or departments at the same level in the organization.
Information exchanged through written words, including emails, reports, and memos.
Information transmitted through spoken words, either face-to-face or via phone/video calls.
The use of digital tools such as email, instant messaging, and video conferencing for communication.
The use of visual elements such as charts, diagrams, and images to convey information.
Obstacles that hinder the effective exchange of information, such as language, noise, and misinterpretation.
Specialized terms or expressions used by a specific group that may be difficult for outsiders to understand.
The ability to influence, motivate, and enable others to contribute toward organizational success.
Theories suggesting that effective leaders possess certain innate characteristics and personality traits.
A leadership perspective emphasizing the role of different types of power in influencing others.
Authority granted through a formal position in the organization.
Influence derived from controlling access to valuable information.
The ability to give benefits, incentives, or recognition to influence others.
The ability to influence others by threatening punishment or negative consequences.
Influence based on specialized knowledge, skills, or expertise.
Influence gained from being admired, respected, or liked by others.
The theory that leadership effectiveness is based on learned behaviors rather than inherent traits.
The idea that effective leadership depends on matching the leader’s style to specific situations.
A flexible leadership style that adapts to the maturity and competence of team members.
The ability to recognize, understand, and manage one’s own emotions while also empathizing with others.
A leadership style focused on inspiring and motivating followers to achieve exceptional results through vision and charisma.
A leadership style based on structured tasks, clear rewards, and punishments.
The ability to understand one’s own emotions, strengths, and limitations.
The ability to empathize with and understand the emotions and needs of others.
The ability to regulate one’s emotions, adapt to changes, and remain goal-focused.
A human resource management approach that views employees as resources to be managed strictly for organizational objectives.
A people-centered HR approach focusing on employee development, motivation, and participation.
An adaptable workforce using different types of contracts and arrangements to meet changing needs.
Permanent, full-time employees who form the essential workforce of an organization.
Non-core employees such as part-time or temporary staff hired for specific tasks or peak periods.
An arrangement where two employees share the responsibilities of one full-time job.
A labor market characterized by short-term contracts, freelance work, and independent contractors.
Work contracts that allow employees flexibility in choosing their start and end times.
Contracts where employees work a set number of hours over a year, scheduled according to demand.
An employment agreement with no guaranteed hours, where work is offered as needed.
A work schedule in which employees rotate or work set shifts to cover 24-hour operations.
A work arrangement where employees complete their total weekly hours in fewer days.
A measure of the output produced per unit of labor input.
The rate at which employees leave and are replaced in an organization.
The habitual non-attendance of employees at work, often measured as a percentage of total work time.
A management approach where managers and employees agree on specific measurable goals and review progress regularly.

Marketing.definition: The process of assessing the size, growth, trends, competition, and potential opportunities in a specific market.
A measure of how sensitive the quantity demanded of a product is to a change in its price.
A measure of the responsiveness of demand to changes in promotional spending.
A measure of how the quantity demanded of a good responds to changes in consumers' income.
The process of designing, creating, and introducing a new product to the market.
Launching a product in a limited market area to evaluate its potential success before a full-scale launch.
A strategy where businesses and customers work together to create value, products, or services.
When a new product takes sales away from an existing product of the same company.
A forecasting method that smooths out fluctuations in data to identify trends by averaging a fixed number of past data points.
A forecasting technique that extends existing trends or patterns into the future.
A forecasting method where expert opinions are gathered through multiple rounds of questionnaires to reach a consensus.
A forecasting method that uses sales staff estimates of future sales based on their market knowledge.
A statistical measure showing the strength and direction of a relationship between two variables.
A forecasting method where a panel of experts provides estimates of future trends.
A marketing strategy where the same product and marketing approach are used across all global markets.
An approach where products, marketing, and services are adapted to suit local markets.
The various ways a business can enter and grow in foreign markets, such as exporting, licensing, franchising, or direct investment.
Selling domestically produced goods or services to foreign markets.
Establishing or acquiring a company in a foreign market to conduct operations directly.
Granting foreign businesses the right to operate under the company's brand and business model.
Allowing a foreign company to produce and sell a product in exchange for fees or royalties.
A business arrangement where two or more companies from different countries collaborate on a project or market entry.
The process of increasing interconnectedness and interdependence of economies, markets, and cultures worldwide.
Cooperative agreements between countries or companies to enhance trade, investment, and development.

Operations Management.definition: The geographical site where a business chooses to establish operations, influenced by factors such as customer proximity, labor availability, infrastructure, costs, and government incentives.
The most efficient and cost-effective site for a business, balancing production costs, market access, supply chain logistics, and workforce availability to maximize profitability.
Relocating business operations or production processes to another country to benefit from lower costs, favorable regulations, or specialized skills.
The process of bringing manufacturing or service operations back to the company's home country after previously outsourcing them abroad.
Cost advantages a business experiences as it increases production, reducing the cost per unit due to more efficient use of resources.
Cost savings that occur within a company as it expands, such as bulk purchasing, specialization of labor, and better utilization of fixed assets.
Cost advantages that benefit all businesses in an industry as the industry grows, such as improved infrastructure, skilled labor pools, and shared suppliers.
The disadvantages of growth where increased production leads to higher per-unit costs due to inefficiencies such as communication breakdowns and coordination issues.
Cost disadvantages that occur within a firm as it grows too large, such as management complexity, reduced flexibility, and declining employee motivation.
Cost increases that affect all firms in an industry due to industry growth, such as congestion, competition for resources, and higher input prices.
The degree to which a product or service meets customer expectations and complies with established standards.
Specific measurable goals set by a company to maintain or improve the quality of its products or services.
The process of inspecting and testing products to ensure they meet required specifications and standards before reaching customers.
A proactive system of planned activities that ensure quality is built into every stage of production, reducing defects before they occur.
A company-wide approach to long-term success that focuses on customer satisfaction, continuous improvement, and employee involvement in quality processes.

A quality philosophy stating that: 1) Quality is conformance to requirements, 2) The system for quality is prevention, 3) The performance standard is zero defects, and 4) Quality is measured by the price of nonconformance.
The practice of comparing a company's processes, performance, and products against industry leaders to identify areas for improvement.
A software system that integrates business processes across departments, improving coordination, efficiency, and decision-making.
Computer-Aided Design: The use of computer software to create, modify, and optimize product designs with high precision.
Computer-Aided Manufacturing: The use of computer-controlled machinery and software to automate production processes.
The ability of a business to adapt production processes quickly to changes in demand, market conditions, or technology.
A company’s capacity to respond rapidly and effectively to market changes and emerging opportunities while remaining efficient.
The creation and introduction of a new or significantly improved product to meet customer needs and enhance competitiveness.
The implementation of new or improved production or delivery methods to increase efficiency and reduce costs.
A production philosophy focused on minimizing waste and maximizing value by streamlining processes.
A Japanese concept meaning 'continuous improvement' where employees at all levels work together to make small, ongoing changes.
Also known as PDCA (Plan-Do-Check-Act), a continuous improvement process for problem-solving and quality management.
Small groups of employees who meet regularly to discuss and solve workplace quality and productivity issues.
An approach where product design and process planning are conducted in parallel to reduce development time.
A production method where teams work on a complete product or part, increasing efficiency and responsibility.
The processes involved in reducing, reusing, recycling, and disposing of waste in an efficient and environmentally friendly way.
A project management tool that identifies the sequence of key tasks that determine the minimum project completion time.
The amount of time a task can be delayed without affecting the project’s overall completion date.
The time a task can be delayed without delaying the start of the next dependent task.
The earliest point in time at which a task can begin, based on the project schedule.
The latest point in time a task can be completed without delaying the project.
The shortest possible time required to complete a project, assuming all resources are used efficiently.
The sequence of tasks in a project that directly determines the project’s minimum completion time; any delay in these tasks delays the whole project.

Finance.definition: The financial gain achieved when total revenue exceeds total costs, representing the surplus available to owners or shareholders.
The financial shortfall occurring when total costs exceed total revenue, indicating a negative financial performance for a period.
Revenue minus the cost of goods sold (COGS), showing the profit from core trading activities before deducting operating expenses.
Gross profit minus operating expenses, indicating the profit generated from normal business operations before interest and tax.
The final profit figure after deducting all expenses, including interest, taxes, and extraordinary items; also called net profit.
A financial report summarizing revenues, expenses, and profits over a period, also known as the income statement.
A snapshot of a company’s financial status at a specific date, showing assets, liabilities, and equity; also called the balance sheet.
Expenses related to borrowing money, such as interest payments on loans, overdrafts, and bonds.
The portion of net profit kept in the business for reinvestment, rather than distributed as dividends.
Payments made to shareholders from a company’s profits, typically as a return on their investment.
Resources owned by a business that have economic value and can generate future benefits.
Obligations the business owes to others, such as loans, trade payables, or other debts.
Assets expected to be converted into cash or used within one year, such as inventory and receivables.
Assets held for long-term use, such as property, machinery, and intangible assets like patents.
Obligations due within one year, such as accounts payable and short-term loans.
Debts or obligations due after more than one year, such as bonds or long-term leases.
The residual interest in the assets of a business after deducting liabilities, representing ownership value.
Profits set aside for specific purposes or retained to strengthen the company’s financial position.
The systematic allocation of the cost of a tangible asset over its useful life to reflect wear, tear, or obsolescence.
A method of valuing inventory based on the estimated selling price minus costs to complete and sell the goods.
Spending on assets intended to benefit the business over the long term, such as equipment or buildings.
Spending on day-to-day operations, such as wages and utilities, that does not create a long-term asset.
The use of financial ratios to assess a company’s performance, liquidity, efficiency, and profitability.
The ability of a business to meet its short-term obligations using its current assets.
A liquidity ratio calculated as current assets divided by current liabilities, indicating short-term solvency.
A stricter liquidity ratio that excludes inventory from current assets before dividing by current liabilities.
A profitability ratio showing operating profit as a percentage of revenue, indicating operational efficiency.
A profitability ratio showing gross profit as a percentage of revenue, reflecting core trading performance.
A profitability ratio showing how efficiently a company generates profit from its capital base.
An efficiency ratio showing how many times a company sells and replaces its inventory in a period.
The average number of days a company takes to pay its suppliers.
The average number of days it takes a company to collect payment from customers.
Ratios that measure the proportion of debt in a company’s capital structure, assessing financial risk.
The total dividends paid divided by the number of outstanding shares.
A profitability measure showing net profit attributable to each outstanding share.
A valuation ratio calculated as the market price per share divided by earnings per share.
The annual dividends per share expressed as a percentage of the share’s market price.
A ratio showing how many times a company’s earnings can cover its dividend payments.
The process of evaluating potential investments to determine their profitability and risks.
Market-wide risk that cannot be eliminated through diversification, such as economic downturns.
Company- or industry-specific risk that can be reduced through diversification.
The time it takes for an investment to generate enough cash inflows to recover its initial cost.
An investment appraisal method using average accounting profit as a percentage of initial or average investment.
The process of adjusting future cash flows to present value using a discount rate.
A valuation method that uses discounted future cash flows to determine an asset’s present value.
The concept that money today is worth more than the same amount in the future due to its earning potential.
The current worth of a future sum of money, discounted at a specific rate.
An investment appraisal measure that subtracts the initial investment from the present value of future cash inflows.
A guideline for evaluating investment opportunities, such as accepting projects with positive NPV.
Quantifiable metrics used to measure business performance against objectives.
Comprehensive documents issued yearly by companies detailing financial performance, governance, and strategy.
An independent opinion on whether a company’s financial statements give a true and fair view.
The comparison of a company’s financial performance over different time periods to identify trends.
The comparison of a company’s financial performance with other businesses in the same industry.
The mix of debt and equity used to finance a company’s operations and growth.
A situation where a business expands too quickly without sufficient working capital, risking liquidity problems.
A competitive strategy focused on becoming the lowest-cost producer in an industry.
The system of rules, practices, and processes by which a company is directed and controlled, ensuring accountability and transparency.
The possibility that a borrower will fail to meet their financial obligations according to the agreed terms, resulting in a loss for the lender.
A specific type of credit risk referring to the likelihood that a borrower will be unable to make the required debt payments, either in part or in full.

Theory of Consumer Behavior.definition: The additional satisfaction or benefit gained from consuming one more unit of a good or service. Marginal utility typically decreases as more units are consumed, reflecting the Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility. For example, eating the first slice of pizza gives more enjoyment than the fourth or fifth slice.

The total satisfaction received from consuming a certain quantity of goods or services. It is the sum of the marginal utilities of each unit consumed. For instance, if each chocolate bar gives some enjoyment, the total utility is the combined enjoyment from all bars eaten.

A principle stating that as a person consumes more units of a particular good, the additional satisfaction from each new unit tends to decrease. This explains why demand curves typically slope downwards.

The rule that consumers maximize their total utility when the marginal utility per unit of currency spent is equal across all goods and services purchased. This principle guides rational allocation of limited income among competing goods.

An economic concept that assumes utility can be measured and expressed in numerical units, allowing direct comparison between the satisfaction gained from different goods. For example, a consumer might say an apple gives 10 utils of satisfaction and a banana gives 8 utils.

An approach to utility measurement that assumes satisfaction cannot be measured in exact numbers but can be ranked in order of preference. For example, a consumer might prefer tea to coffee, and coffee to juice, without specifying by how much.
A decision-maker who allocates income to maximize total satisfaction, making choices based on marginal utility, prices, and budget constraints.
The additional satisfaction gained from spending one more unit of currency on a good or service. It is calculated by dividing the marginal utility of a good by its price.

An observation that some goods essential for survival (like water) often have low market prices, while non-essential goods (like diamonds) may have high prices. This is explained by differences in marginal utility and scarcity.
The total utility from all units consumed divided by the number of units. It provides an idea of the average satisfaction per unit.

A graph showing different combinations of two goods that give the consumer the same level of satisfaction. Along an indifference curve, the consumer has no preference for one combination over another.
A collection of indifference curves representing a consumer’s preferences over a range of goods. Higher curves represent higher levels of satisfaction.
The rate at which a consumer is willing to give up units of one good in exchange for an additional unit of another good while maintaining the same level of satisfaction.
A graph showing all possible combinations of two goods a consumer can buy given their income and the prices of the goods. It represents the consumer’s spending constraint.

Theory of Consumer Behavior.term: Law of Diminishing Marginal Rate of Substitution
Theory of Consumer Behavior.definition: A principle stating that as a consumer substitutes one good for another, the willingness to give up units of the first good to obtain an additional unit of the second good decreases.
The point at which a consumer has allocated their income in a way that maximizes total satisfaction, given prices and budget constraints.
Goods that can replace each other completely in consumption, providing the same level of satisfaction. For example, two brands of bottled water.
Goods that are consumed together in fixed proportions to maximize satisfaction, such as left shoes and right shoes.
A graph showing how the quantity of a good consumed changes as the consumer’s income changes, holding prices constant.
The total effect of a change in the price of a good on the quantity demanded, composed of both the substitution effect and the income effect.
The change in quantity demanded of a good resulting from a change in the consumer’s real income or purchasing power.
The change in quantity demanded due to a change in the relative price of goods, making one good more or less attractive compared to others.
Represents the rate at which one good can be substituted for another without changing total expenditure. It equals the negative ratio of the prices of the two goods.
The property that indifference curves are bowed towards the origin, reflecting a consumer’s preference for balanced consumption bundles over extremes.
The principle that if a consumer prefers good A to good B, and good B to good C, then they will prefer good A to good C, ensuring consistency in choices.
The point of maximum satisfaction on an indifference map, beyond which any change in consumption would reduce satisfaction.
A type of inferior good for which an increase in price leads to an increase in quantity demanded due to a strong negative income effect outweighing the substitution effect.
Goods for which demand decreases as consumer income rises, such as instant noodles for higher-income consumers.
The assumption that more of a good is always preferred to less, holding other factors constant.
A rule stating that indifference curves cannot intersect, as this would imply contradictory preferences.

Economic Efficiency and Market Failure.definition: Producing a given level of output at the lowest possible average cost with current technology and inputs. In diagram terms, firms operate at the minimum point of the long-run average cost curve or on the production possibility frontier. Waste is minimized and resources are fully utilized.

Resources are allocated to produce the mix of goods and services most valued by society, where price equals marginal cost (P = MC). At this point, the last unit produced yields a marginal benefit equal to its marginal resource cost, so no reallocation can improve welfare. It is a key benchmark for well-functioning competitive markets.

Efficiency achieved over time through innovation, R&D, learning-by-doing, and investment that reduce costs or improve product quality. It reflects how quickly and effectively firms adapt technologies and processes. Market structures with healthy competitive pressure and the expectation of future profits tend to promote dynamic efficiency.

An allocation of resources where no one can be made better off without making someone else worse off. It is a strict efficiency criterion that says nothing about fairness or equality. Many Pareto-efficient outcomes can exist, including ones with very unequal distributions.

When firms produce above the minimum possible cost due to weak competition, managerial slack, or poor incentives. Costs are higher than technically necessary even with the same technology. It is often associated with monopolies or heavily protected industries.

Producing the maximum feasible output from a given set of inputs, or using the minimum inputs for a given output, given current technology. Technically inefficient firms lie inside the production possibility frontier. It focuses on physical input–output relationships, not prices.

The extra cost to society from producing one more unit of a good, including both private production costs and any external costs imposed on third parties. Formally, MSC = MPC + MEC. In the presence of negative externalities, MSC exceeds private marginal cost.

The additional benefit to society from consuming one more unit of a good, including the private benefit to buyers plus any positive spillovers to others. Formally, MSB = MPB + MEB. With positive externalities, MSB exceeds private marginal benefit.

The extra cost to the producer of making one more unit, excluding any external costs. It is the cost relevant to a firm’s supply decision in the absence of regulation. In competitive markets without externalities, MPC equals MSC.
The additional benefit to the individual consumer from one extra unit consumed, reflected in the demand curve. It excludes any spillover benefits to others. Without externalities, MPB equals MSB.

The additional cost imposed on third parties when one more unit is produced or consumed. Examples include pollution, congestion, or noise. When MEC > 0, unregulated markets overproduce relative to the social optimum.

The extra benefit enjoyed by third parties when one more unit is consumed or produced. Examples include herd immunity from vaccination or knowledge spillovers from R&D. When MEB > 0, markets underprovide the good without intervention.

The difference between total social costs and total social benefits for an activity when costs exceed benefits (NSC = TSC − TSB > 0). A positive net social cost indicates a welfare loss relative to doing less of the activity. Policymakers aim to reduce activities with high net social costs.

The excess of total social benefits over total social costs (NSB = TSB − TSC). The socially efficient policy or output is the one that maximizes NSB. On MSC–MSB diagrams, this occurs where MSC equals MSB.

Spillover costs from the production process borne by third parties, such as pollution from factories or environmental damage from resource extraction. The private supply curve (MPC) lies below the social cost curve (MSC), causing overproduction and a deadweight welfare loss. Corrective tools include Pigouvian taxes, regulation, and tradable permits.

Spillover costs from consumption that harm third parties, such as second-hand smoke, noise, or drunk driving risks. Private demand (MPB) exceeds social benefit (MSB), leading to overconsumption. Policy responses include excise taxes, age limits, bans in public spaces, and information campaigns.

Spillover benefits to others from a person’s consumption, such as vaccination, education, or healthy behaviors that reduce public health costs. MSB lies above MPB, so the market underconsumes. Subsidies, vouchers, or public provision can raise consumption toward the social optimum.

Spillover benefits created during production, like knowledge diffusion from R&D or training that raises workers’ future productivity. MSC lies below MPC (or equivalently MSB > MPB), so the market underproduces. Policy tools include R&D tax credits, patents, and targeted subsidies.

A situation where the free market, left alone, does not allocate resources efficiently, resulting in welfare loss. Common causes include externalities, public goods, market power, information failures, and factor immobility. Well-designed government policies can sometimes improve outcomes.

Goods that generate private and external benefits but are underconsumed in free markets due to information gaps or myopia (e.g., education, vaccinations). Governments encourage consumption via subsidies, free provision, or information campaigns. The aim is to move consumption closer to where MSB = MSC.

Goods that create private and external costs and tend to be overconsumed (e.g., tobacco, harmful drugs). Consumers may underestimate risks or addiction. Policy responses include taxes, age restrictions, advertising bans, and warnings.

Once provided, it is difficult or costly to prevent non-payers from using the good. This leads to free-riding and underprovision by private markets. Classic examples are street lighting and national defense.
One person’s use of the good does not diminish the amount available for others. The marginal cost of serving an extra user is near zero. Pure public goods are both non-rivalrous and non-excludable.

When individuals benefit from a good without paying, relying on others to fund provision. This undermines market incentives to produce public goods. Collective funding (e.g., taxation) or excludability mechanisms can address it.

Goods that are both non-excludable and non-rivalrous, such as national defense or lighthouse services. Private markets underprovide them because producers cannot easily charge users. Governments often finance provision through taxation.

Goods that are partially excludable or become rivalrous beyond a capacity threshold (e.g., uncongested roads are non-rival, but congestion creates rivalry). Smart pricing or access control can improve efficiency. They lie between pure private and pure public goods.

Taxes levied on unexpectedly high or ‘windfall’ profits, often in sectors like energy or commodities. Intended to capture extraordinary gains not due to firms’ own effort or investment. Critics warn about discouraging future investment if used unpredictably.

A behavioral economics approach that alters ‘choice architecture’ to steer people toward better decisions without restricting options or significantly changing incentives. Examples include default enrollment in pensions or opt-out organ donation. Nudges are low-cost and preserve freedom of choice.

A market dominated by a single firm with significant entry barriers, allowing price-making power. Output is typically restricted and prices elevated relative to competitive levels, creating deadweight loss. Remedies include regulation, antitrust action, or fostering entry.

Setting price equal to marginal cost (P = MC) to achieve allocative efficiency. Under natural monopoly, P = MC may be below average cost, requiring a subsidy to avoid losses. Regulators sometimes use average-cost or price-cap rules as practical alternatives.

The output level where marginal social benefit equals marginal social cost (MSB = MSC). At this point, net social benefit is maximized and no further welfare gains are possible by changing output. Externalities shift the MSB or MSC curves and move the optimal output away from the private market equilibrium.

When public intervention intended to correct market failure leads to a worse allocation of resources. Causes include information problems, regulatory capture, political incentives, administrative costs, and unintended consequences. Effective policy design requires humility, evaluation, and sunset clauses.

When buyers or sellers lack accurate, timely, or comprehensible information to make good decisions. It includes uncertainty, complexity, and bounded rationality. Consequences range from under- or over-consumption to mispriced risk.

A form of information failure where one party to a transaction knows more than the other (e.g., sellers know the quality of used cars better than buyers). It can lead to market collapse or misallocation. Solutions include disclosure rules, warranties, signaling, and screening.

When a party is protected from the consequences of risk and therefore behaves more riskily after a contract is signed (e.g., insured drivers being less careful). It arises from hidden actions. Deductibles, co-payments, and monitoring help mitigate it.

When hidden information before contracting leads to a disproportionate share of high-risk or low-quality entrants (e.g., sicker people more likely to buy health insurance). Markets may unravel as average quality falls. Screening and risk-based pricing are common remedies.

A conflict of interest and information between a principal (owner) and an agent (manager) whose actions are hard to observe. Agents may pursue their own goals rather than the principal’s. Incentive contracts, performance pay, and governance checks align interests.

A corrective tax set equal to the marginal external cost at the socially optimal output, shifting private incentives to internalize the externality. It raises the private marginal cost so that MPC + tax ≈ MSC. Examples include carbon taxes and congestion charges.

A subsidy set equal to the marginal external benefit to encourage activities with positive spillovers. It raises private marginal benefit so that MPB + subsidy ≈ MSB. Examples include R&D tax credits and vaccination subsidies.

An environmental policy that sets an overall emissions ‘cap’ and issues tradable permits equal to that cap. Firms that reduce emissions cheaply sell permits to those facing higher abatement costs, equalizing marginal abatement costs across firms. The cap guarantees the environmental outcome while trading minimizes total compliance cost.

An individual or group not directly involved in a transaction who is nonetheless affected by it. Third parties bear external costs (e.g., pollution harm) or reap external benefits (e.g., herd immunity). Their interests are central to externality analysis.

A direct participant in a transaction or activity—typically the decision-maker such as the buyer/consumer or producer/seller. Their private costs and benefits are captured by MPC and MPB. Policy seeks to align first-party incentives with social outcomes.

The counterparty to the first party in a transaction (e.g., buyer vs. seller). Together, first and second parties internalize private costs and benefits but not externalities. Contracts and market prices reflect their private information and incentives.

Rights to emit a specified amount of a pollutant that firms can buy and sell. Under a cap-and-trade system, total permits equal the emissions cap; trading directs abatement to the lowest-cost reducers. Proper monitoring and enforcement are essential for effectiveness.

Production, Costs, Revenues and Firm.definition: The shortest possible time frame in economics during which supply is fixed and cannot respond to changes in demand, often because production cannot be altered instantly. Prices adjust to clear the market, but output remains constant.
A time period in which at least one factor of production is fixed while others can be varied. Firms can change labour and raw materials but not plant size or capital equipment.
A period of time long enough for all factors of production, including capital, to be varied. Firms can adjust scale of operations, enter or exit the industry, and change all inputs.
A period in which technological change, regulation, and market structures can alter significantly, allowing innovation to affect production methods and costs.
Business expenses that do not vary with the level of output, such as rent, insurance, and salaried staff wages. These costs are incurred even when production is zero.
Costs that change directly with the level of output, such as raw materials, hourly wages, and utility expenses for production.
States that as additional units of a variable factor are added to fixed factors, output initially increases at an increasing rate, then at a decreasing rate, and eventually may decline.
When increasing units of a variable input are added to fixed inputs, the marginal product of the variable input eventually declines.
The sum of fixed costs and variable costs for a given level of output. It represents the overall expense of production.
The additional cost of producing one extra unit of output, calculated as the change in total cost divided by the change in output.
The additional output produced by adding one more unit of a variable input, holding all other inputs constant.
The total quantity of output produced by a firm using a given set of inputs over a certain period.
The total product divided by the number of units of the variable input used, showing productivity per unit of input.
When adding more of a variable input leads to proportionally greater increases in output.
When each additional unit of a variable input produces less additional output than the previous unit.
When adding more of a variable input actually reduces total output due to overcrowding or inefficiencies.
Cost advantages a firm experiences as it increases output, leading to lower average costs due to factors like bulk purchasing and specialization.
The rise in average costs that occurs when a firm grows too large, often due to coordination problems, bureaucracy, or communication issues.
When all inputs are increased by a certain percentage and output increases by a greater percentage, reducing average costs.
When increasing all inputs by a certain percentage results in a less-than-proportional increase in output.
States that a firm can replace one input with another while maintaining the same level of output, within technological limits.
Cost savings that occur within a firm as it increases production, such as managerial specialization or bulk purchasing.
Cost benefits that all firms in an industry experience as the industry grows, such as improved infrastructure or a larger skilled labour pool.
Increased average costs due to inefficiencies within a firm as it expands, like management difficulties or worker demotivation.
Increased average costs affecting all firms in an industry as it expands, such as traffic congestion or rising input prices.
The lowest level of output at which a firm can achieve the minimum possible average cost in the long run.
The total income a firm receives from selling goods or services, calculated as price multiplied by quantity sold.
Revenue per unit sold, found by dividing total revenue by the quantity sold. In a competitive market, it equals the market price.
The additional revenue a firm earns from selling one more unit of output.
The total amount of money received from sales of goods or services, calculated as price times quantity.
The total opportunity cost of production, including both explicit and implicit costs.
The opportunity costs of using resources owned by the firm for production instead of in their next best alternative use.
The actual monetary payments a firm makes for inputs purchased from others.
Suggests that the main goal of a firm is profit maximization, achieved where marginal cost equals marginal revenue.
Proposes that managers may prioritize objectives other than profit maximization, such as revenue growth or market share.
Views firms as coalitions of individuals with different interests, making decisions based on satisficing rather than maximizing.
When firms aim for a satisfactory level of profit while pursuing other objectives like growth or market share.
The process of producing the level of output where marginal cost equals marginal revenue, resulting in the highest possible profit.
When a firm produces at the output level where marginal revenue equals zero, aiming to maximize total revenue rather than profit.
When a firm focuses on selling as much output as possible, often subject to a minimum profit constraint.
The difference between total revenue and total economic costs, including both explicit and implicit costs.
The difference between total revenue and explicit costs, ignoring opportunity costs of owned resources.
Profits above the normal level required to keep a firm in the industry, providing an incentive for new firms to enter.
The minimum profit necessary to keep a firm operating in the long run, where total revenue equals total economic cost.
When total revenue is less than total economic costs, signaling that resources could be better used elsewhere.

Production, Costs, Revenues and Firm.term: Survival Conditions in the Short Run
Production, Costs, Revenues and Firm.definition: A firm can continue operating as long as revenue covers variable costs, even if total costs are not fully covered.

Production, Costs, Revenues and Firm.term: Survival Conditions in the Long Run
Production, Costs, Revenues and Firm.definition: In the long run, a firm must cover both variable and fixed costs to remain in business.
The difference between sales revenue and variable costs, used to cover fixed costs and generate profit.
A firm that makes production decisions aimed at maximizing objectives, such as profit, given resource constraints and market conditions.

Market Structures.definition: A market structure with many small firms selling identical products, free entry and exit, perfect knowledge, and no barriers to entry. Firms are price takers and produce at the allocatively efficient point where price equals marginal cost (P = MC) in the long run.

A market structure where a single firm dominates supply, often protected by high barriers to entry. The monopolist is a price maker, can restrict output to raise prices, and may produce at a point where price exceeds marginal cost (P > MC), leading to allocative inefficiency and potential deadweight loss.

A market structure with many firms selling similar but differentiated products. Firms have some price-making power due to brand loyalty or product differences. In the long run, profits are driven to normal levels due to low entry barriers, but there may still be excess capacity.

A market structure with a small number of large, interdependent firms. High barriers to entry and potential for collusion or non-price competition. Behavior is often strategic, and game theory is used to predict outcomes.

A special case of oligopoly where only two firms dominate the market. Their strategic choices strongly influence each other’s outcomes, often leading to tacit or explicit collusion, or competitive rivalry.
A monopoly that arises when a single firm can supply the entire market at a lower average cost than multiple firms due to significant economies of scale, often in utilities like water or electricity.
Markets with low entry and exit barriers, where the threat of potential competition forces incumbent firms to behave competitively, even if only one or a few firms operate at a time.

Agreements between competing firms, usually in oligopoly, to fix prices, limit production, or divide markets. They are illegal in many countries due to their anti-competitive effects and the deadweight loss they cause.

An oligopoly model suggesting that firms face a demand curve that is more elastic for price increases and less elastic for price decreases. This leads to price rigidity, as firms are reluctant to change prices for fear of losing market share or triggering price wars.
A situation in oligopoly where one firm (often the largest or most efficient) sets the price and others follow. It can be tacit collusion without explicit agreements.
An oligopoly where firms compete without formal agreements, often relying on non-price competition like advertising, branding, and product differentiation to gain market share.
An oligopoly where firms coordinate pricing and output decisions to maximize joint profits, either through explicit agreements (cartels) or tacit understandings.
Obstacles that make it difficult for new firms to enter a market, including economies of scale, brand loyalty, patents, capital requirements, and government regulation.
Barriers created by laws or regulations, such as patents, licenses, and exclusive government contracts, that limit market entry.
A measure of the market share of the largest firms in an industry, typically expressed as CR4 or CR8, indicating the percentage of total output controlled by the top 4 or 8 firms.
A game theory model where rational players, acting in their own self-interest, end up with a worse outcome than if they had cooperated. Common in oligopoly pricing decisions.
The study of strategic interactions where the outcome for each participant depends on the choices of others. It’s widely used to model behavior in oligopolistic markets.
Strategies to make a product distinct from competitors’ offerings through design, quality, branding, features, or customer service. It reduces price elasticity of demand.
Charging different prices to different customers for the same product, where the price difference is not due to cost differences. Requires market power and the ability to prevent resale.
Also called perfect price discrimination, where each customer is charged the maximum they are willing to pay, capturing all consumer surplus as profit.
Charging different prices based on the quantity purchased or product version, such as bulk discounts or premium versions.
Charging different prices to different groups of consumers based on their price elasticity of demand, such as student or senior discounts.
When firms in an oligopoly indirectly coordinate actions, such as price levels, without formal agreements, often through signaling or observing competitors’ behavior.
A tendency for prices in oligopoly to remain stable despite changes in costs or demand, often explained by the kinked demand curve model.
A pricing strategy where an incumbent firm sets a price low enough to deter entry by potential competitors, even if it sacrifices short-term profits.
A point where a market can no longer absorb more of a product due to full penetration, leading to slower sales growth and greater competition.
The strategic awareness that each firm’s decisions affect competitors’ outcomes, leading to reactive behavior and potential coordination.
Firms in perfectly competitive markets that must accept the market price determined by supply and demand, as they have no market power.
A strategic situation where one participant’s gain is exactly balanced by another’s loss. Total net benefit across players is zero.
A game theory concept where no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing strategy, given the strategies of others.
The horizontal summation of all individual firms’ supply curves in a perfectly competitive market. In the long run, supply adjusts to changes in demand through firm entry and exit.
